Iron rods used in the 19th century to connect blocks of marble have corroded the columns they were intended to support. The restoration work is to be completed in 1995. The architects will receive an $80,000 award for their design.

DOC.HEAD: John Paul Visits Prison of `Living Hell'
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Sunday visited an infamous prison known as ``he Living Hell,'' where he prayed with AIDS victims and urged drug traffickers to go straight. John Paul told 300 inmates in the prison chapel that faith could help them escape an underworld of drug-trafficking, violence and the Mafia. The theme has marked the pope's five-day visit to the Naples region, his longest pastoral journey in Italy. ``My dear friends, I have come to invite you to have patience, to seek goodness and mutual understanding,'' the pontiff told the inmates, most of them in their 20s, clad in jeans. ``Think about your families, sorely tried by your condition; think about those who love you and count on you. Carry a little serenity within you, even in this place and among yourselves.'' The 71-year-old Poggioreale prison is the most notorious in crime-ridden Naples because of overcrowding and poor conditions. Built for 1,000 prisoners, it housed 2,700 until recently, when several hundred were transferred to a new prison. Many prisoners are detained on drug charges, and 600 are drug addicts, according to the prison. Among Poggioreale's most famous inmates was Raffaele Cutolo, a convicted murderer and boss of the Camorra, the Neapolitan Mafia that controls an international network of cocaine trafficking. On Sunday, the pope saw little of the drudgery that has earned the prison the nickname ``The Living Hell'' among Neapolitans. A fresh coat of cream-colored paint covered the prison walls and the bright white chapel was spotless. But a young prisoner, in a short speech, told the pope the inmates lived in ``sad conditions.'' ``Above all, when we return to our families, we want to find a society ready to receive us and to make us feel once again that we are men, and useful citizens of the community - just like everyone else,'' the prisoner cried, to the cheers of inmates. Several waved small yellow-and-white Vatican flags or olive branches symbolizing peace. As the pope left, the street-hardened toughs bent to kiss his ring. They beamed as he warmly greeted them. ``I feel so full of emotion,'' one young inmate told a reporter before a security guard reimposed himself in front of the prisoners. After the ceremony, the pope walked to the ward reserved for about 50 AIDS victims. He shook the men's hands and tenderly stroked their hair, then prayed briefly with them. Crime, drugs and unemployment have been important themes of the pope's trip to Naples, which began Friday. The city has remained a symbol of urban blight and Mafia power in a nation emerging as a European economic powerhouse. On Saturday, John Paul visited the city's worst slum, urging residents to ``not give in to evil.'' He also criticized local politicians for cronyism and appealed for a ``recuperation of legality.'' The pope's trip to Poggioreale occurred the day after the national government enacted measures to limit early releases from prison. An embarrassed Justice Minister Giuliano Vassalli said during the papal ceremony that the measures ``do not in the least affect the laws and acts aimed at making prison life more humane and dignified.''

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Get A Good Whiff of Gas in Chemical Warfare Training
With AM-Bush-Gulf Strategy, Bjt
LaserPhoto RM3
DOC.TEXT: His eyes teared, his nose ran and his lungs burned. But Spec. 4 Eric Hackman could do little but endure te discomfort caused by tear gas wafting through an Army gas chamber. Hackman, 24, of Latrobe, Pa., and other Fort Eustis soldiers got a good whiff of the gas as part of their training in the use of masks and clothing designed to protect them from chemical weapons. The soldiers had been through the training before. They knew how to suit up and clear their masks by breathing out hard. But events in the Persian Gulf were making the refresher course particularly timely. ``In the event he goes to Saudi Arabia and if he doesn't do the procedure properly, does not clean the mask properly, he could be exposed to the chemical, get sick - die,'' said Maj. Frank Connor, chief of the Training Division at Fort Eustis. About 230,000 U.S. troops have been sent to the Persian Gulf since Iraqi President Saddam Hussein sent his army into neighboring Kuwait on Aug. 2. Saddam has stockpiles of chemical weapons and has used them against the Kurds in eastern Iraq. U.S. soldiers train regularly in putting on their protective gear and performing their jobs. ``If you are a truck driver, you have to be able to do your truck driving in an NBC environment,'' said Sgt. 1st Class Larry Price, head of the post's ``NBC'' - nuclear, biological, chemical - branch. Hackman and others volunteered to remove their masks inside the chamber, a tent set up in a forest clearing. Some commanders require it as part of the training. Others do not. The exercise is intended ``so you will be confident (in the mask) when you go into the battlefield,'' said Staff Sgt. Marvin Ward. The smell of the gas seeped from the tent and the wind blew it on those waiting their turn. ``Let's get it over with,'' one soldier said. About 10 masked soldiers filed into the chamber. When they left 10 minutes later with their masks off, they were bent over, coughing and waving their hands. ``Don't touch your face,'' cautioned Sgt. Donna Niemuth, in charge of the chamber. ``Look into the wind.'' Hackman's eyes were redder than most. ``You want to rub your eyes,'' said Hackman, of the 155th Transportation Company based at Fort Eustis. ``Right before I got out the door, I got a good breath.'' Spec. 4 Richard Hill, also of the 155th, wasn't as bothered by a runny nose. ``I blew it good before I went in there,'' Hill said. ``It burns. I want to scratch my eyes. There's a real nasty taste in my mouth.'' The tear gas wore off in about 15 minutes. The soldiers also spend time in the classroom, learning about chemical agents much stronger than tear gas. Price taught a recent class to members of the Army Reserve's 359th Transportation Battalion based in nearby Hampton. Price told them there are four NBC tenets: avoidance, protection and decontamination, and pulling all three together to perform in a contaminated environment. Chemical warfare agents include nerve gas, blister agents like mustard agent, and blood agents that strip oxygen from the blood. They can be fatal or incapacitating, Price said. The effects of some agents wear off quickly; others can last many years. Nerve agents cause loss of muscle control and affect nerve endings, Price said. ``How many of you took Black Flag and sprayed it on a bug?'' he asked. ``That's what nerve agent does to you.''

DOC.HEAD: Actor Of Ancient Greek Tragedy Dies
DOC.TEXT: Alexis Minotis, Greece's best-known tragic actor, died Sunday. He was 84. Minotis suffered a stroke on Saturday and died early Sunday, the Athens News Agency reported. Minotis was born in Khania, Crete, in 1906 and spent 65 years in the theater. He was best known for his roles in classical Greek tragedy. He also wrote essays and was artistic director of the National Theater for many years. Minotis married actress Katina Paxinou during World War II and they left for the United States. Paxinou had a successful stage and film career, winning an Academy Award in 1943 for best supporting actress in the film of Ernest Hemingway's novel ``For Whom The Bell Tolls.'' The couple returned to Greece in 1951. Paxinou died in 1973. Minotis was removed from the National Theater by the right-wing military dictatorship in 1967. He returned after its fall in 1974 only to be removed again by the socialist government that came to power in 1981. Minotis last appeared on stage in Samuel Beckett's ``Endgame'' in 1988, in a performance that he also directed. He had planned to direct Shakespeare's King Lear this winter.

DOC.HEAD: Baker To Brief Canadian on Recent Diplomatic Mission on Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III will discuss the Persian Gulf situation with Canada's foreign minister Joseph Clark on Tuesday, the State Department said Sunday. Baker will travel to Bermuda to meet with Clark, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said in a statement. Baker returned Saturday from an eight-day diplomatic mission to Europe and the Middle East, where he consulted with officials from nine nations on Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the subsequent international sanctions and the U.S. troop buildup in the Persian Gulf. ``The secretary will brief Minister Clark on those meetings and they will discuss the Persian Gulf in general,'' Tutwiler said. Baker will return to Washington the same day.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployed Republican Unseats Democrat With $600 Campaign
LaserPhoto BX1
DOC.TEXT: Donna Lambert, an unemployed factory worker, made out well in the Massachusetts ``throw-the-bums-out'' election. Running a $600 campaign, she beat the incumbent for a $56,000-a-year job as the Middlesex County register of probate. ``I am a very nice person who loves people and I am not a politician,'' said Lambert, 56, a Republican. ``I'm a grandmother that's been elected to an office.'' Lambert's Democratic opponent, Tom Larkin, was appointed to the post by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis in 1989 after his predecessor was made a judge. He was surprised by the election results, which gave Lambert a lead of more than 40,000 votes. ``She won fair and square. The numbers are clear,'' Larkin said. Lambert has been collecting $144 a week in unemployment since she was laid off from her job with a baby clothes manufacturing company last June. That job paid $19,000 a year. Her husband works as an electrical engineer for Polaroid Corp. The register of probate's term is six years in Middlesex County, which includes diverse urban and rural-suburban areas around Boston. Lambert said she may use the extra money from her new job to install a swimming pool at home. Lambert graduated from high school in Newton, and then did what she called ``hands-on training'' raising four children. She had a real estate broker's license at one point, but it has expired. ``I think she's in a state of shock. She didn't expect to win,'' said Larkin. The register of probate oversees 100 employees and processes more than 12,000 new cases a year, including divorces, child support cases and wills. There are eight judges who work full-time for the court, Larkin said. Larkin has two master's degrees, one in psychology and another in public administration from Harvard University. He also has 10 years of experience as a county commissioner, as well as experience as the director of special education for the Boston school system. Larkin blamed his loss, in part, on the fact that Lambert's name came first on the ballot. He also said the anti-incumbent sentiment, which propelled a Republican governor into the Statehouse to replace Democrat Dukakis, fueled a vote for the Republican challenger. ``It's one way to get off unemployment, but she's going to have a lot to learn,'' he said. Lambert said she has long been involved with the Republican Party, as a member of the Republican town committee, and said she has done work at election polls. While working at the polls, she noticed Republicans never fielded candidates for county jobs. ``So I said `That's it, I'll look and see and I'm going to run,''' she said. Larkin spent about $25,000 on the primary campaign, and $5,000 to run against Lambert. His strategy included some television ads, bumper stickers, and a series of lawyers' breakfasts. Lambert's campaign cost $600, and consisted largely of a letter-writing effort. She had green and beige business cards made up and mailed them to about 200 people, picked at random from voter registration lists and the telephone book.

DOC.HEAD: Child Sex-Abuse Case Drags on in Picturesque Carolina Town
DOC.TEXT: Colonial-style buildings still line the business district in this town on Albemarle Sound that once was North Carolina's colonial capital. The picturesque small town retains a quaint charm. But Edenton also is the site of the state's biggest and most complicated child-abuse case. Prosecutors allege that over the course of a year at the Little Rascals Day Care Center, 29 children were sexually assaulted by the owners, employees and a friend of the owner. All seven deny the charges. With more than 400 counts, the case exceeds that of the McMartin Pre-School trial in California in which the defendants were acquitted earlier this year. One of those defendants, Raymond Buckey, was tried a second time, but the prosecution ended with a deadlocked jury in July and the charges were dropped. The McMartin case consumed seven years of court time ad cost Los Angeles County more than $13.5 million, making it the longest, most expensive criminal court case in U.S. history. Many of Edenton's 5,800 residents are uneasy discussing the case here. Many have close friends on both sides, and District Attorney H.P. Williams has asked residents not to spread ``unfounded'' statements about the case. ``I'm getting tired of hearing about it,'' said Steve, an attendant at a service station who wouldn't give his last name. ``I wish they'd just get going and get it over with. A lot of people feel that way.'' The case broke when someone lodged a complaint in January 1989 alleging abuse of children at the center. The state Child Day Care section in Raleigh revoked the center's license in March 1989 and one of the center's owners, Bob Kelly, was arrested shortly after. Prosecutors allege that children between the ages of 2 and 7 were raped, sodomized and assaulted. The indictments allege that most of the assaults occurred between September 1988 and January 1989. The defendants are Little Rascals co-owners Kelly, 41, and his wife, Elizabeth Twiddy Kelly, 34; Willard Scott Privott, 40; Darlene McDonald Harris, 25; and three former employees of the center - Shelley Alyce Stone, 34; Kathryn Dawn Wilson, 24; and Robin Boles Byrum, 19. All but two remain in jail in lieu of bond. All seven could face multiple life sentences if convicted. The case hit a snag in October when the judge handling the case cited its ``complexities'' and withdrew after the state Supreme Court overturned his ruling that the defendants should be tried separately. A new judge was selected. ``I would say we may not be at square one, but we're certainly at square two,'' said Joe Cheshire, a lawyer representing Mrs. Kelly, referring to the new judge. The new judge is still looking over the case, Cheshire said Sunday. ``He is reviewing the file and I assume we are waiting for a court date at which we will discuss where we stand.'' He said no decision had been made on whether the defendants would stand trial together or in small groups. Bill Hart, a lawyer from the state attorney general's office assigned to help prosecute the case, said that the earliest it could go to trial would be January. ``We're hoping (the trial) will only take six to eight weeks,'' Hart said. ``Of course, you never can guarantee about the length of a trial.'' Cheshire said that in his opinion, a January trial is``highly unlikely, seeking as how it's almost Thanksgiving.'' A civil suit filed against Mrs. Kelly provides a glimpse into what kind of case the prosecution could present. ``We anticipate that some of the children will testify, some of parents will testify and counselors will testify,'' said C. Everett Thompson II, a lawyer representing the plaintiffs in the negligence suit. The suit has been put on hold at the request of prosecutors. Some of the children are still troubled, Thompson said. ``They're going through therapy, they're getting treatment,'' he said. ``We think it will be a long time before we really know the extent of the damage and the scarring that occurred to these children.''

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Links Base Access to Lifting of Trade Embargo
DOC.TEXT: Vietnam has offered to allow the United States to use a former U.S. naval base if Washington lifts a 26-year-old trade embargo, the official Vietnam News Agency reported Sunday. The offer by Communist Party chief Nguyen Van Linh also applies to Japan, which follows the boycott, said the agency, monitored in Bangkok. The agency report was based on an interview given by Linh to Japan's NHK television company. The former U.S. base at Cam Ranh Bay, about 175 miles northeast of Ho Chi Hinh City, formerly Saigon, has been a Soviet military site since the Vietnam War ended in 1975. The Soviet Union has said it maintains no more than a token presence at Cam Ranh Bay and intends to withdraw completely. Vietnam's foreign minister, Nguyen Co Thach, has said the withdrawal would be completed by 1992. The trade embargo was imposed on Communist North Vietnam in 1964 and was extended to the entire country following the fall of the U.S.-backed Saigon government in 1975. Washington has had no diplomatic relations with Vietnam since the war ended. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Thach met in October. Linh said he hope relations with Japan would improve if ties with Washington were normalized. ``I know that Japan wants to cooperate and do business with Vietnam, but it is tied to the U.S. policy of embargo. I believe Japan will be more resolved to do business with Vietnam,'' he said. Linh also told the Japanese network that Vietnam would permit U.S. and Japanese investment around the country, the agency reported. ``If you want to do business, you may invest not only in Cam Ranh, but in other ports as well,'' Linh was quoted as saying. In the news agency report, Linh appeared to confirm reports that he took part in a three-member delegation that visited Beijing in September. The reported meeting with Chinese Premier Li Peng, would have been the highest level contact between the countries since their border war in 1979 following Vietnam's invasion of Cambodia. But Linh said Cambodia was just one of the obstacles to normalization of relations with China. ``There has been misunderstanding ... on the Cambodian issue as well as on bilateral relations. This misunderstanding is being removed gradually. The two countries have stopped firing at each other and are conducting cross border trade,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Governemnt Troops Claim 19 Tamil Rebels Killed
DOC.TEXT: Government troops killed 19 Tamil rebels and one soldier died in at least four battles around Sri Lanka, military officials said Sunday. There was no word on the reported skirmishes from the rebels, who have waged a seven-year fight against the Sinhalese-dominated government for an autonomous homeland. The government claim could not be independently confirmed. The officials, who cannot be identified under briefing rules, said troops destroyed many underground bunkers Saturday, killing nine militants. Also, one soldier was killed and five were injured in fighting near Trincomalee, a port city 150 miles northeast of Colombo. Four rebels died when their truck was straffed by a helicopter gunship Saturday in the northern town of Chavakachcheri, 185 miles north of Colombo, the officials said. They said a naval gunboat destroyed a fishing trawler near the Pungudutivu village, also in the north, killing four rebels. The vessel was believed to be used by guerrillas for gunrunning. Two rebels were killed near Manmunai village in the eastern Batticaloa district. The officials did not say when the two attacks took place. More than 14,000 people have been killed in the civil war. Tamils claim they are discriminated in jobs, education and the use of Sinhala language. Tamils make up 18 percent of the island's 16 million people. The Sinhalese comprise 75 percent of the population and control the government and the military.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Generals Arrive for Visit, Praise East-West Cooperation
DOC.TEXT: Two NATO generals arrived Sunday in the first visit to the Soviet Union by high-ranking military officials of the Western alliance. American Gen. John R. Galvin, the alliance's supreme military commander in Europe, and Norwegian Gen. Vigleik Eide, chairman of NATO's military committee, were welcomed at Moscow's Sheremetyevo Airport by Soviet Gen. Mikhail Moiseyev, chief of the general staff, the official Tass news agency reported. Eide told Tass that he was satisfied with the better relations between leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and Warsaw Pact countries. ``The present relations between military leaders of the two blocs are distinguished by their frankness and a sincere desire for compromises on all issues,'' Tass quoted him as saying. ``We should move from confrontation to cooperation to greater openness and mutual trust,'' Eide said, according to the independent Interfax news service. Galvin and Eide will hold several days of talks with political and military officials, including perhaps President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, then go on separate visits to different parts of the Soviet Union. Eide will go to Leningrad to meet with regional military officials, and Galvin will visit the Kiev Military District and the Soviet Black Sea fleet in Sevastopol before returning to Belgium. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze was the first foreign minister of a Warsaw Pact nation to visit NATO headquarters in a symbolic end to East-West military hostilities. Moiseyev visited the 16-member Western alliance last month.

DOC.HEAD: Blood Test Could Target Women Likely to Miscarry
DOC.TEXT: A simple blood test conducted before pregnancy might be a new way of identifying women at high risk of miscarrying, according to research published in a British medical journal. Writing in the Nov. 10 edition of The Lancet, the researchers said it was the first time that measuring hormone levels before a woman conceives has been found to predict whether a pregnancy will be successfully carried to term. The doctors tested for the luteinising hormone (LH), which controls ovulation. Dr. Lesley Regan, Dr. Elisabeth Owen and Professor Howard Jacobs tested 193 women planning to become pregnant. The women ranged in age from 21 to 43, with a median age of 30.7. The obstetricians from the Rosie Maternity Hospital, Cambridge and University College Medical School wrote that 88 percent of the women with normal LH levels conceived within 18 months. Only 67 percent of the women with abnormally high LH levels conceived within that period. In the normal LH group, 12 percent of the women suffered miscarriages. In the high group, 65 percent miscarried. The doctors concluded that a raised serum LH concentration in the early phase of pregnancy confers a substantial risk of miscarriage. The finding offers the possibility of a simple predictive test for women before pregnancy. An abnormal result could also be used to identify patients that could be treated to suppress excessive secretion of LH.

DOC.HEAD: Police Officials Replaced in Temple Mount Shakeup
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with police force shakeup, soldier wounded in West Bank. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Two top police officials were replaced in a shakeup stemming from last month's Temple Mount killings, officials said Sunday. The Cabinet, meanwhile, discussed a compromise move to allay international criticism of Israel over the Oct. 8 Temple Mount shootings, in which 20 Arabs were killed by police gunfire. Also Sunday, authorities announced 2,400 more Palestinians would be banned from entering Israel for security reasons, and an Israeli soldier was shot and wounded in the West Bank. In the police shakeup, Jerusalem police chief Aryeh Bibi and Rachamim Comfort, commander of the southern police district which includes Jerusalem, were reassigned. Both were strongly criticized in a government report on the Temple Mount killings. The report, compiled by a three-member investigating team, condoned the use of live fire on stone throwers and said Palestinians started the riot, but criticized police for failing to anticipate the violence. In the wake of the report, Police Minister Roni Milo decided to create a new police district in Jerusalem. Chaim Albaldes, currently head of the central police district, will become commander of the new district, thus removing Bibi. Comfort was replaced by Rafi Peled, currently chief of the National Police intelligence department. The report had criticized both Comfort and Bibi for bad judgment and mistaken assessment of intelligence data in the Temple Mount incident. Israel radio reported that Comfort and Peled will work together for several months, and then Comfort would retire early. Bibi's name was not included in the list of new appointments. The radio said he was expected to be moved to another post which would not entail a promotion in rank. Jerusalem was swept by a wave of Jewish-Arab street clashes following the Temple Mount shootings. In recent weeks, police strength in Jerusalem reached 2,000 officers, about one-eighth of the police force for the entire country. In the Cabinet discussion of international criticism over the Temple Mount shootings, ministers suggested Sunday they would be willing to welcome a U.N. envoy - if the visit was not directly tied to a Security Council resolution condemning Irael. Foreign Minister David Levy told army radio that a compromise was being discussed both at the United Nations and with U.S. officials in Washington. He acknowledged the government was trying to head off another Security Council resolution that could call for specific steps against Israel, and was hoping to persuade Washington to veto such a move. ``All our efforts are aimed at preventing a negative decision regarding Israel and we are acting in every way possible including the strengthening of our understanding with the United States,'' Levy said. The decision to ban more Palestinians from entering Israel brings to 10,800 the number of Arabs from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip who are blocked from visiting or working in Israel. The decision was announced by Shmuel Goren, the coordinator for the occupied territories. He said on Israel radio that the program would cover Palestinians from ``security and criminal categories, those who the police and security elements believe constitute a security risk.'' Military government spokesman Shmuel Ozenboy said the move would take effect this week, but he would not be more specific. About 110,000 residents of the territories captured by Israel in the 1967 Middle East war work in Israel. Palestinians have complained new limits on workers could hurt the territories' economy since few jobs are available outside Israel. The soldier who was wounded Sunday was shot near Bet El, a Jewish settlement in the West Bank about 10 miles north of Jerusalem, the army command said. It said assailants in a car fired at him as he was waiting at a bus stop, and the soldier fired back, the army said. The soldier suffered arm and leg wounds, but they were not serious, the army added.

DOC.HEAD: Art Dealers On Auction Bidding: `The Party's Over'
DOC.TEXT: Last week's contemporary art sales confirmed that the steam has gone out of the art market, according to art experts, and more disappointing prices could emerge this week in sales of works from the estates of Henry Ford II and Greta Garbo. The euphoria that once gripped auction rooms is gone amid fears of a U.S. recession. But if the market has fallen, it's far from dead, experts say. Speculators who didn't know Pissarro from Picasso may have departed but serious collectors who know art and buy for the long term are bidding. ``What we are missing are the headline-grabbing situations that we had in the last couple of years,'' said William E. O'Reilly of Salander-O'Reilly Galleries Inc. ``Now I think we have a more conservative buying public ... whereas perhaps there was more of a festival mood about it before.'' Sotheby's auction of postwar art Tuesday was certainly no festival. Fewer than half of the works offered - 34 out of 77 - were sold, the rest failing to reach the minimum price the sellers had in mind. And the total for the sale was $19.8 million, only half of the lowest pre-sale estimate by the auction house. Christie's sale the following night was a bit more upbeat. Thirty of the 58 lots sold for a total of $36.7 million, against a pre-sale estimate by the auction house of $47.7 million to $65.4 million. Willem de Kooning's ``July,'' a large abstract canvas of fractured shapes and obscured colors painted in 1956, sold for $8.8 million, well above its high-end estimate of $7 million. ``The very top market usually sustains itself,'' said Bonnie Barrett Stretch, editor of the ARTnewsletter, a biweekly report on the international art market. ``True masterpieces sustain prices through thick and thin.'' That may not bode well for this week's sale of impressionist paintings since art experts agree that few outstanding works are up for sale. If sales are sluggish, they say, it will have more to do with the quality of the art offered than the state of the market. Stretch says the absence of great art works has to do with luck of the draw and a reluctance among some owners to sell in the current market. The art collection of the late Henry Ford II will be auctioned on Monday at Sotheby's. The most important work is Renoir's ``Cup of Chocolate,'' an oil on canvas painted about 1878 of a young woman seated with a cup and saucer at her side. The pre-sale estimate for the painting is $15 million to $18 million. On Thursday, the art collection of film legend Greta Garbo will go on the block at Sotheby's. Sotheby's is counting on people buying because of the Garbo name, said Harry Brooks, director of Wildenstein Co. Inc., a New York art gallery. ``But there are really only three important Renoirs and a Bonnard,'' he said. ``If that sale doesn't do well that doesn't mean anything because the whole sale is sort of overblown.'' Christie's will sell a still life by Vincent van Gogh on Wednesday. ``Vase With Daisies and Poppies,'' painted in the French town of Auvers shortly before his death in 1890, has a pre-sale estimate of $12 million to $16 million. None of these prices approaches the staggering records set during the spring auction sales, when van Gogh's ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' brought $82.5 million at Christie's and Renoir's ``At the Moulin de la Galette'' fetched $78.1 million at Sotheby's. The total estimate for the art to be auctioned at the two houses during the two weeks of major fall sales is $508 million to $665 million. The May series of sales brought $925.7 million. Allan Stone, a New York dealer, says the auction rooms had become ``theaters of the absurd'' in recent years. Not only did great art realize record-breaking prices but lesser art fetched higher prices than good art in galleries. ``The New Year's Eve party is over. People are doing their homework,'' he said. The auction houses will have ``to weed out the material that comes in and offer just the best quality stuff.''

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Promises Visit to Troubled Soviet Troops in Germany
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl promised to visit Soviet troops in eastern Germany after Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev expressed concern over reported problems facing the soldiers, a government spokesman said Sunday. Gorbachev on Saturday ended a two-day trip to Germany during which he signed a 20-year treaty of non-aggression, friendship and cooperation. But he returned to Moscow without receiving any commitment for economic aid beyond the $19.5 billion already promised by the German government and banks. Most of the aid is to pay for withdrawing the troops and for housing and retraining in the Soviet Union. On Friday, Gorbachev mentioned in a speech his concern over an ``anti-Soviet flavor'' in German public attitudes toward the 380,000 Red Army soldiers remaining in former East Germany. A government spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, confirmed a report in the conservative Welt am Sonntag newspaper that Kohl promised he would visit Soviet military camps in the coming year and speak with the troops. The Soviet military forces are scheduled to withdraw over the next four years, and there are reports of poor morale, extortion, desertions and violence among the soldiers already. The two Germanys united on Oct. 3 and the nation became a NATO member. The German magazine Stern, in its most recent edition, said older soldiers were beating up younger ones to force them to hand over their pay. It also said the number of suicides among the troops was high. Soviet troops lead closely restricted lives in the German bases, but there are German news reports that some have deserted to live in the forests and others are stealing weapons and military hardware to sell on the black market.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Singer David Crosby, comic Jay Leno and wrestler Hulk Hogan straddled motorcycles Sunday and led thousands of bikers on ``Love Ride 7'' to benefit the Muscular Dystrophy Association. ``For some crazy reason we feel that if we all ride together maybe we can come up with enough money and a miracle to whip this disease,'' Hogan said before heading out for an afternoon rendezvous in the Malibu hills. The wrestler said he got involved because he's a parent and cares about kids. ``I've had mothers call me up and cry and kids beg me to help,'' Hogan said. ``I've seen it all.'' Last year, the event attracted 7,000 bikers and raised more than $500,000 for MDA. This year's crowd was estimated to reach 10,000 by the end of the day. The ``Love Ride'' is a 100-mile journey from a Harley-Davidson dealership in Glendale to the Calamigos Ranch in the Santa Monica Mountains north of Malibu. Participants pledge a minimum $40 and are treated to an afternoon of food and music, including performances by Crosby and Jackson Browne. Proceeds benefit MDA's six Los Angeles County clinics. --- NEW YORK (AP) - What's inspiration sound like in the brain of comedian and actor Robin Williams? Something like ``Bing!'' Williams says some of his happiest moments have been when his improvisation comes together while he's doing a stand-up comedy routine. ``When you find that new idea, when you come up with a concept and find that it works, it's the creation of the moment that's so incredible,'' Williams said in Sunday's The New York Times Magazine. ``And you know, they've discovered there actually is a slight endorphin release during creative moments,'' he said, referring to a brain chemical. ``It's like, Bing! This is part of evolution.'' Williams, who has been nominated for two Academy Awards for his roles in ``Good Morning, Vietnam'' and ``Dead Poets Society,'' stars in the movie ``Awakenings,'' which is due out next month. ``Awakenings,'' which also stars Robert De Niro, is based on a book of medical case studies by the neurologist Oliver Sacks. --- RADNOR, Pa. (AP) - Andy Griffith says he'll take down his lawyer's shingle after this season, his fifth as the title character of NBC's ``Matlock.'' ``I'm financially comfortable. I'm in my 60s and there's no reason to stay around,'' the 64-year-old actor said in the Nov. 17 issue of TV Guide. ``After this season, I'm leaving, and that's it.'' But the show's executive producer, Fred Silverman, said he thinks the odds are 50-50 that Griffith will sign for another season. Griffith says Silverman is wrong. ``I know I want to go home, is all. ... I don't need any pressure on me, people thinking they see an opening and coming after me,'' Griffith said. ``I went through that, one season in the '60s, and I lost all of my determination to quit then. I'd just as soon not see that happen again.'' Griffith planned on quitting CBS's ``The Andy Griffith Show'' in 1967 after seven seasons. His contract had expired and he hoped to prove wrong those who attributed his success in the role of Andy Taylor ``to some nonsense that I was only playing myself.'' But the network offered him a salary figure he called staggering, and he relented. Now, Griffith said, ``it's time to wrap it up.'' ``I've enjoyed the show, but I don't need this grind anymore,'' he said. ``Time to move on. I want to go home.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - What's money, anyway, reasons Ray Charles, who says that after all, he can sleep in only ``one bed at a time.'' In the Nov. 17 issue of People magazine, Charles said he doesn't buy into some of the praise his peers have heaped on him over the years, such as Frank Sinatra's once calling him ``the only genius in the business.'' ``I'll get all the accolades, but at my best I will never make half the money Sinatra has made,'' said Charles, known for such hits as ``Hit the Road, Jack'' and ``What'd I Say.'' ``But when you break it down, what does it matter? I can only sleep in one bed at at a time. I can only make love to one woman at a time,'' he said. Charles, 60, has nine children, ages 14 to 40, by seven women, and seven grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Struggle to Save Downtown Mount Vernon as Flooding Subsides Upstream
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of volunteers joined National Guard and Army Corps of Engineer troops Sunday in a battle to save Mount Vrnon's downtown from the rain-swollen Skagit River. ``We are in a full flood fight,'' said Dave Brookings, Skagit County assistant flood control engineer. But elsewhere, many of the more than 500 residents displaced by near-record flood levels on seven northwest Washington rivers were returning home, and most dikes and levees held in low-lying areas. Three houses were lost in an isolated resort town, and officials said damage to roads, bridges and homes and businesses from flooding Friday and Saturday would run to millions of dollars. High water, slides and washouts closed numerous roads and highways, including the Trans Canada Highway north of Hope, British Columbia, about 90 miles east of Vancouver. No injuries were reported. The three-day deluge was produced by the ``Pineapple Express,'' what National Weather Service forecasters call a fall storm route from Hawaii to the Pacific Northwest. In Mount Vernon, with a population of about 14,500, Brookings said 400 to 500 people filled sandbags as the Skagit River crested at 35.2 feet, 7.2 feet over flood stage. Three to four feet of sandbags were piled atop a 34-foot revetment protecting the downtown area, Brookings said. ``This is all just flat farmland,'' he said. ``After it gets over the levees, that water just keeps spreading.'' Downstream, where the Skagit divides before emptying into Skagit Bay, about 60 people were evacuated late Saturday from Fir Island and 50 or so left Conway, Brookings said. Dozens of people filled sandbags to shore up shaky dikes near Conway to try to prevent the displacement of an additional 500 to 600 people, he said. ``It looks like we've got it under control,'' he said. He said approximately 150 people forced from their homes in three areas near Concrete, about 30 miles east of Mount Vernon and 60 miles north of Seattle, would begin returning home Sunday. The Skagit would have risen about 3 feet higher at Mount Vernon had floodgates not been closed upstream at Seattle City Light and Puget Sound Power & Light Co. hydroelectric dams, said Larry Merkle of the Army Corps of Engineers reservoir control center in Seattle. In Whatcom County, the most hard-hit by flooding Friday and Saturday, damage could approach $10 million, said Bill Quehrn of the county Department of Emergency Services. About 200 people were evacuated from Sumas on the Canadian border and dozens more from Everson, but most were returning Sunday as the water subsided, Quehrn said. ``The towns that were flooded yesterday are drying out,'' he said. ``It's down to puddles in the street.'' About 100 people in and around the Lummi Indian Reservation north of Bellingham were displaced after dikes failed along the lower Nooksack River. A plugged storm drain led to the evacuation of 15 to 20 people from a dozen homes about 16 miles south of Bellingham, Quehrn said. The resulting two-acre pond, as deep as 25 feet, was undermining a scenic highway and draining toward the homes, which range from expensive year-round residences to summer and vacation cottages overlooking Samish Bay, he said. At Glacier, 40 miles east of Bellingham, three homes in the Glacier Springs subdivision tumbled 40 to 50 feet into Canyon Creek, which eroded the bank. In Snohomish County, the main concern was for dikes protecting Ebey Island, home to about 300 to 400 people in the Snohomish River east of Everett. A few miles upstream, two hours of sandbagging by about 40 people averted major flooding at Snohomish, said Al Amonson, staff coordinator in the Snohomish County Department of Emergency Management. ``They caught it just in time,'' Amonson said.

DOC.HEAD: From the Practical to the Bizarre, It's All For Sale At Brothel Auction
DOC.TEXT: A little bit of everything will be for sale when the Mustang Ranch brothel falls under an auctioneer's gavel Tuesday, from household items to gaudy relics of America's best-known sporting house. ``We highly encourage the neighborhood yard sale enthusiast to come out and make a bid on anything they may want,'' said Internal Revenue Service manager Dierdre Pagni. Ms. Pagni conceded that, despite her agency's familiarity with such sales, it's hard to predict what the turnout will be for the bankruptcy auction. ``We've never done this with the Mustang Ranch before,'' she said. The event is expected to draw curiosity seekers as well as serious bidders. IRS agents padlocked the 104-room bordello on Sept. 21, three days after the property owned by Joe and Sally Conforte was forced into bankruptcy liquidation. The government's intent is to recoup a portion of the $13 million in back taxes it says is owed by the Confortes. The auction has been advertised in newspapers around the country, including The Wall Street Journal. The IRS hopes to get at least $1.8 million, largely from the sale of the ranch's real estate holdings. Two buildings which make up the ranch compound will be sold separately, as will a 60-unit trailer park in nearby Lockwood and the 440 acres surrounding the brothel, 10 miles east of Reno just off Interstate 80. So far the brothel has piqued interest as a potential nursing home, a halfway house and a home for wayward girls. Even a religious group has inquired about the property, although the IRS has remained mum on details. While Tuesday's auction will cover many of the types of items found at a typical garage sale, there are others that definitely are not. Amid the lamps, couches and bottles of booze are large paintings of nude women, a painting of Conforte, boxes of condoms and framed posters pointing out the locations of Nevada's legal bordellos. There even is a picture of heavyweight boxer Oscar Bonavena, who was gunned down at the gates of the Mustang in 1976 by Conforte bodyguard Willard Ross Brymer. The Confortes started the Mustang Ranch, illegally at first, in the 1950s. In 1960, local authorities proclaimed it a public nuisance and burned it to the ground. But a decade later Conforte won approval from Storey County to operate the brothel, paving the way for legalized prostitution in most rural Nevada counties. County commissioners last month revoked the permit allowing prostitution at the Mustang Ranch, saying they would never again endure the circus atmosphere that has surrounded it the past 35 years.

DOC.HEAD: American Servicemen in Persian Gulf Remember Past Veterans
With AM-Veterans Day, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. troops in the Mideast on Sunday remembered those who died for their country, and some wondered whether there would be casualties from the Persian Gulf crisis to mourn next year. The human cost of any offensive against Iraq to liberate Kuwait is ``a question that's on everybody's mind,'' said 2nd Lt. Benjamin Lacy, 23, of Largo, Fla. He is with the Army's 15th Financial Support Unit. ``It looks like many people will be marching in next year's Veterans Day parades with a banner saying Desert Shield '90-'91,'' he said. Veterans Day was not a holiday for the 230,000 American troops deployed in the Persian Gulf, but many remembered their fellow soldiers who fought in previous wars. ``I know that we're over here now to protect American interests and personally myself, I think about the people that served in Vietnam,'' said 2nd Lt. Tony Ferguson, 31, of Bahama, N.C. He belongs to the North Carolina National Guard, which was activated for Desert Shield. ``And that's what Veteran's Day is about to me, remembering the people who gave their lives for our country in the past.'' For Lacy, Veterans Day ``means many people before me put their life on the line. Many died, some are scarred for life. It's time to honor them.'' Forty-six soldiers have died so far in Operation Desert Shield, which was launched in response to Iraq's Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait. At a religious service at his desert camp on Saturday night, he said, the chaplain delivered a homily on Veterans Day and the importance of honoring those who served their country. Sgt. Terry L. Wright, 43, the postmaster of Pinellas Park, Fla., arrived here Saturday with the 37th Air Evacuation Unit, a reserve unit activated about 10 days ago. ``I feel bad about having to be here today,'' he said. ``If I was home, it would be a holiday, and I'd be drinking beer and putting my feet up.'' British servicemen also remembered their war dead Sunday on their country's Remembrance Day. The Irish Hussars, one of the British regiments, had a small ceremony with bagpipes and a bugler.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Of Man Charged With Smuggling Jet Fighters To Begin
DOC.TEXT: A shadowy trade in armaments abandoned by the United States at the end of the Vietnam War will be illuminated in a trial scheduled to begin this week in federal court. Cenon Rey Avelino, a Canadian citizen of Filipino origin, is accused of trying to smuggle two Cessna A-37 Dragonfly jets from Vietnam into the United States after selling the jets to undercover U.S. Customs agents for $306,000. The light attack planes, dismantled and crated, were seized a year ago by Customs agents at Buffalo's international Peace Bridge. Avelino was later indicted on charges ranging from money-laundering to violating the Trading with the Enemy Act. His trial begins Tuesday before U.S. District Judge John T. Elfvin and is expected to last about three weeks. Avelino, who has been held without bail since his arrest, could face more than 10 years in prison if convicted on all charges. Avelino, 40, of suburban Toronto, is portrayed in court papers as a globe-trotting arms dealer who boasted he could obtain a variety of military hardware abandoned by the United States in Vietnam. The Pentagon has estimated that nearly 1,000 military planes, including 113 Dragonflys, were abandoned in Vietnam when the United States pulled out in 1975. Also abandoned were 940 naval ships and boats, 42,000 trucks, 791,000 M-16 rifles and a large amount of other assorted weaponry. Avelino told the agents he represented the government of Vietnam and could get $18 million worth of arms from that country, according to statements filed in court by U.S. Customs and Royal Canadian Mounted Police officers. Federal officials have said they are concerned that Vietnam may be selling abandoned U.S. arms to Third World countries unfriendly to the United States. At a pretrial hearing last winter, the customs agent in charge of the case, C.W. Moore, said agents had considered trying to get Avelino to work for them so the U.S. government could acquire more of the abandoned arms and keep them from falling ``into the hands of madmen.'' That idea was scuttled when the Customs Service and the Defense Department refused to pay for the scheme, Moore said. U.S. Attorney Dennis C. Vacco has said the undercover agents who dealt with Avelino in Toronto and Jacksonville, Fla., portrayed American businessmen. He refused to say what reasons the agents gave for wanting the jets. James Harrington, Avelino's lawyer, has said his client is a legitimate businessman who never concealed his ties to the government of Vietnam. The jets had been sitting idle for 15 years and were in no shape for combat, Harrington said. He said Avelino understood the agents wanted them for parts. The A-37, according to Air Force manuals, can carry various combinations of rockets and bombs under its wings. The planes also could be equipped with 7.62mm machine guns. A-37s, which could fly more than 500 mph and higher than 40,000 feet, originally cost U.S. taxpayers more than $1 million apiece when they were built in the 1950s and '60s. Avelino told Customs agents at the border that his cargo included dismantled jets. But he misrepresented the type of aircraft and declared their value to be only $36,000, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Forty Arrested as Soccer Rowdies Rampage in Eastern Germany
DOC.TEXT: Hooligans smashed cars and broke windows after soccer games in two cities in eastern Germany, and police arrested 40 people, the ADN news agency said. Violence broke out after a game in Magdeburg on Saturday between the local team and Dynamo Dresden, ADN said. Before and during the game, which FC Magdeburg won 3-1, there was no trouble. But rival fans fought outside the stadium after the game ended, ADN said late Saturday. Police moved in to break up the fights and escorted visiting Dresden fans to the local train station to make their connections home, it said. Later, about 150 mostly young hooligans, some wearing ski masks, began rampaging through downtown Magdeburg, smashing windows with rocks, and destroying a car, ADN said. The violence abated after police arrested 29 people, the agency said. A day earlier, in Rostock, about 30 soccer holligans rampaged through the downtown, smashing windows and plundering a liquor store, after local team FC Hansa beat Sachsen Leipzig 2-1. No injuries were reported in the riots, although police arrested 11 people, according to ADN. Police said most of those detained in both riots were released after identity checks. Charges of property damage and disorderly conduct were expected to be filed against some of them, ADN reported. The riots came one week after fans turned violent in Leipzig after a soccer match. In that violence, police shot and killed an 18-year-old man. Police said the shooting was in self-defense after rioters attacked officers. Fan violence in the former East Germany has increased recently, leading officials to consider canceling a game in Leipzig on Nov. 21 between the world champion German national team and former East German national players.

DOC.HEAD: Snow & Rain In Northeast, Warmer In West
DOC.TEXT: Rain and snow were scattered from the Great Lakes into the Northeast on Sunday, while parts of the West warmed to record highs. Snow fell over northern Maine during the early afternoon, and from south-central New York state across east-central New York state. Snow showers extended over southern and eastern Michigan. A winter weather advisory was posted into early Monday over New York state's western Mohawk Valley and the western Adirondaks. Wind was expected to gust to more than 30 mph into Monday and produce wind chill factors below zero. Heaviest snowfall during the six hours up to 1 p.m. EST was 1 inch at Limestone, Maine, and Sault Ste. Marie, Mich. At the same time atop New Hampshire's Mount Washington, the highest mountain in the Northeast at over 6,200 feet, the temperature was 5 above zero and wind gusted to near 115 mph, producing a wind chill of 46 below zero. Rain was scattered over northeastern Illinois and southeastern Wisconsin. Rain also fell along the northern coast of Washington state, where three days of steady rain had caused extensive flooding. Sunday's low for the Lower 48 states was 10 at Gunnison, Colo., and Truckee, Calif. But other spots in the West hit record highs, including 63 at Kalispell, Mont.; 86 at Santa Maria, Calif., and 72 at Sheridan, Wyo. Spokane, Wash., tied its record of 60, set in 1892. Elsewhere, Hollywood, Fla., cooled to 51 during the morning for a record low. And Fairbanks, Alaska, chilled to 34 below zero, one degree below the previous record set last year. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 23 at Warroad, Minn., to 89 at the San Diego Naval Air Station.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Prepares for Atlantis Countdown
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be topped after start of countdown at 10:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: NASA on Sunday prepared for the launch of the space shuttle Atlantis, which is to carry a spy satellite into orbit after being grounded for months by fuel leaks. The countdown was to begin at 10:30 p.m. EST. Atlantis is scheduled to lift off Thursday sometime between 6:30 p.m. and 10:30 p.m. EST. The precise time will not be announced until nine minutes before launch because of the classified nature of the military mission. Atlantis' five astronauts will deploy the satellite, which published reports say will spy on Iraq. It is believed to be a photographic imaging or an eavesdropping spacecraft. The mission originally was planned for July, but was put on hold when Atlantis was found in June to have hydrogen leaks. Columbia also was crippled by hydrogen leaks, and NASA temporarily grounded the entire three-shuttle fleet. NASA replaced Atlantis' external fuel tank, hydrogen lines between the orbiter and tank, and valve seals. A fueling test last month found the shuttle to be free of dangerous leaks. During the interim, the Air Force is reported to have modified the satellite so it could spy on Iraq. Atlantis has not flown since March, when it conducted another secret Pentagon mission. Its upcoming trip will be the 37th shuttle flight and the seventh mission dedicated entirely to the Defense Department. The flight is expected to last four days. A public blackout will be imposed throughout the mission, and no information will be released. NASA plans to launch Columbia about two weeks after Atlantis' mission, if all goes well. Columbia has been waiting for the astronomy mission since May, when hydrogen leaks halted the first of four failed countdowns.

DOC.HEAD: Paul McCartney: `I'm a Ham'
DOC.TEXT: Paul McCartney says he's a ham and never tires of the public's adulation. ``I like being recognized on the street,'' the singer-songwriter was quoted Sunday as saying in The New York Times. ``I like having lorry (truck) drivers in New York lean out their windows saying, `Yo, Paul, thanks for the music,''' he said. ``It's a big city, the capital of the world almost and they all know me. That's what I did it for. I'm a ham.'' The ex-Beatle says he sometimes listens to bootleg music, which is not to say he supports the making of such recordings. ``If you start making the alternate takes available, in 10 years people may not know which was the finished take and which wasn't,'' McCartney said. ``I'd rather avoid the confusion.''

DOC.HEAD: Humane Society Proposes Breeding Ban To Stop Pet Overpopulation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `It calls...', to delete reference to buyers being required to neuter pets within a year; ordinance is not specific on that point.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FX1
DOC.TEXT: Local humane society officials are pressing for an ordinance to ban all breeding of dogs and cats. It's not that they are against puppies and kittens, they just want to stop killing 10,000 unwanted animals each year. The debate over the proposed breeding ban is shaping into a class battle fought by responsible pet owners and breeders of aristocratic pets, and shelter workers who must euthanize thousands of those pets' poorer cousins each year. ``What is radical is what we've been doing, killing animals,'' said Kim Sturla, executive director of the Peninsula Humane Society. ``I think it's crazy that it's become acceptable to kill dogs and cats.'' Under the proposal, believed to be the first of its kind in the nation, pet owners found in violation would face fines ranging from $100 to $500. Penalties would be waived if the animals are spayed or neutered. ``It doesn't seem right. If people allow their animals to roam outside, then I understand why they should be spayed or neutered,'' said Carolyn Varner of San Mateo County, who is selling two 5-month-old registered Persian kittens for $175 each. ``But my cats are indoor cats and they aren't allowed to go breed every time they go into heat.'' The proposed ordinance, which would apply to unincorporated areas in this affluent county of 600,000 south of San Francisco, is designed to reach zero pet population growth. It calls for a one-year moratorium on breeding and then mandatory spaying and neutering of cats and dogs. Pet stores would still be allowed to import puppies and kittens, but the animals would have to be neutered. Opponents argue that it is unenforceable. Breeders, they say, would lose a livelihood and animals spayed and neutered to comply with the new law would be barred from many competitions. San Mateo County Supervisor Tom Nolan, the ordinance's sponsor, said he expects some details may be modified after public hearings that begin Tuesday before the county board of supervisors. But Nolan says the tragedy of euthanizing thousands of animals a year ultimately outweighs other concerns. ``If you put show and prize animals as one value next to an ordinance that might potentially save 10,000 dogs or cats a year, I imagine the choice is clear,'' Nolan said. Sturla said there are no large-scale breeders she is aware of in San Mateo County. ``I would challenge anybody to show me anyone making a living off breeding animals, except `puppy mill'-ers,'' Sturla said. ``We're certainly having an impact on somebody's hobby, but we're not having an impact on anyone's livelihood.'' And Nolan said he is less interested in catching every violator than encouraging pet owners to be responsible. ``My hope is that ... there will some kind of social sanctions attached to the person in the neighborhood who lets their dog or cat go around without being spayed or neutered,'' he said. Of the roughly 15,000 animals brought to the shelter each year, 1,500 are returned to their owners and 3,500 are adopted, according to Humane Society figures. The remaining 10,000 animals are killed. As if the statistics weren't attention-grabbing enough, the Humane Society recently euthanized several animals in front of reporters. ``We're trying to illustrate to the public that 10,000 is not just a statistic,'' Sturla said. ``They are living, feeling animals.'' The reporters ``experienced what we experience every single day. They got to see fear on the animal's face, to see the animal tremble and see her defecate in the hallway on the way to the kennel,'' Sturla said. ``What we're attempting to do is drag the euthanization of dogs and cats out of the closet,'' Nolan said. ``When you see it, you understand its a barbaric practice.''

DOC.HEAD: Veterans Day Ceremonies Made More Solemn by Threat of Mideast War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 5 grafs with Scruggs remarks and finalists for Vietnam Women's Memorial
DOC.TEXT: Americans paid tribute to the dead of wars past in solemn Veterans Day ceremonies Sunday at the Tomb of the Unknowns and the Vietnam Veterans Memorial amid fears that the nation may be swept into a new war in the Persian Gulf. At the Vietnam memorial, Bob Horsch of Rahway, N.J., a veteran of Army service in Vietnam, said he believed it was ``just a matter of time'' until the United States was at war again. Horsch said he believed the military buildup in the Persian Gulf was justified by the need to protect American interests and those of other countries. Stephen Reuben of Lapwai, Idaho, a member of the Nez Perce tribe who also served in Vietnam, declined to say whether the buildup was a good idea, but also said he fears the country was headed for war. ``I am afraid so, but I pray and hope we don't,'' Reuben said. Teresa Swain of Hagerstown, Md., when asked if she supported the buildup, said ``We have to protect our interests.'' As to whether it would mean war, she said ``I certainly hope not.'' Mrs. Swain said she has a son-in-law in the Air Force. Speakers at the ceremonies, including Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, paid tribute to the American troops now serving in the gulf region. At Arlington National Cemetery, Cheney laid a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknowns and addressed a capacity crowd in the adjoining Vermont marble amphitheater, which seats 5,500. ``Those who have been deployed to the Persian Gulf and Saudi Arabia are probably the best trained soldiers we have ever had,'' he said. ``The nation and the world will be better for their service.'' ``People who are concerned about peace must stay prepared for war,'' Cheney said. The ceremonies, held on traditional Veterans Day in advance of Monday's official national holiday, took place under bright, sunny skies, with a crisp wind whipping through the flag-draped amphitheater at Arlington. At the Vietnam memorial, an armed services color guard and a bagpiper playing ``Abide With Me'' accompanied military and patriotic groups who placed wreaths in front of the 58,000 names inscribed on the ebony-colored, granite wall. They are the names of American servicemen killed in Vietnam. Col. Robert F. Foley, an Army Medal of Honor winner from Vietnam, told the crowd ``The situation in Saudi Arabia is a grim reminder that war is not a thing of the past.'' The National Park Service estimated the crowd at 5,000. Jan C. Scruggs, president of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fund, his voice breaking, spoke of the troops in the Middle East, saying, ``We are very, very proud of them and we do hope that in the event there is combat they will not get the treatment that the Vietnam veterans got.'' Meanwhile the Vietnam Women's Memorial Project announced the selection of two finalists in its competition for a design of the memorial, to be built alongside the Vietnam Veterans' Memorial. The target date for its dedication is 1992. One of the winning designs, by sculptor Eileen Rose Barry of East Islip, Long Island, is a statue of a woman standing by herself with a helmet in her hand. The other, by landscape architect Robert Desmond of Arlington, Mass., consists of a white marble block, in contrast to the black marble of the wall, surrounded by 240 jets of water. Diane Carlson Evans, director of the project, said the two finalists would be asked to refine their proposals and the final design would be a collaboration of the two. Raquel Ramati, a New York urban designer who served on the nine-person jury of designers and veterans, said the panel was split. The veterans favored a representational sculpture and the designers leaned toward an abstract design.

DOC.HEAD: John Silber Says His Fiery Temper May Have Done Him In
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in penultimate graf
DOC.TEXT: John Silber, the on-leave president of Boston University, acknowledges his fiery temper may have cost him the governor's chair. Silber, who was the Democratic nominee, lost Tuesday to Republican William Weld by about 76,000 votes out of more than 2 million cast. Silber, in an article for The Boston Sunday Globe, said he might have been hurt by outbursts, which drew attention throughout the race. ``These faults hardly add up to a temperament unfit to govern, but perhaps they cost me 50,000 votes,'' he wrote. ``If they did, then perhaps I did blow the election, although I am not sure.'' Silber concluded he was probably the victim of his own testiness and an anti-incumbent, anti-Democrat mood that swept Massachusetts on Election Day. ``It is tempting to excuse one's performance and also wonder whether one could have won by doing a little better,'' he said. ``Or to put it more bluntly, to take comfort in thinking that you have just been run over by the locomotive of history or to experience the disquieting thought that you've blown an election that you could have won. In my case, I can see evidence for both diagnoses,'' Silber said. Silber acknowledged his vitriolic exchanges with television newswomen Natalie Jacobson and Lesley Stahl also hurt his campaign. In an interview with Jacobson, Silber said he believed the high number of working mothers led to a generation of abused and neglected children. He also refused to respond when she asked him to name his strengths and weaknesses. Silber spread the blame, saying he was the victim of ``sound-bite'' journalism and a Democratic Party out of step with voters. ``When I began the campaign for the governorship, I said that although I could do the job, I didn't need it. I still believe that, and so do my family,'' he wrote. Silber, a Texas native, said his outspoken style would better serve a Texas politician but was ``easily misinterpreted in Massachusetts.'' Late in the campaign, Silber referred to Weld as an ``orange-headed WASP'' and a ``back-stabbing son of a bitch.'' Silber apologized for the SOB remark. ``In the genteel atmosphere of New England, these were used to divert attention from more important issues,'' Silber said.

DOC.HEAD: Pilgrims See Crosses in Bathroom Window
DOC.TEXT: Crowds of people have been lining up to get into Leo and Loretta Alphonso's bathroom, where Mrs. Alphonso reported the images of two crosses appeared on a window shortly after she finished a series of prayers. ``I went in skeptical,'' said visitor Evelyn Rodriguez. ``I didn't know what to expect but I sure didn't expect that. I was amazed. I was really amazed.'' The Roman Catholic archdiocese of New Orleans had not heard about the crosses, a spokesman said. Pilgrims led into the small, darkened room off the Alphonsos' bedroom report seeing the images of two crosses - one gold, one white, both about 10 inches high - on the surface of a small, translucent window. Visitors point out that there are no lights in the Alphonso's back yard that might cause the patterns. Some doubted that a white street light and a yellow porch light about a half-block away could be the cause. ``Sure, I could see those street lights,'' Ms. Rodriquez said. ``But I don't see how they could have caused the crosses. Those crosses are absolutely gorgeous.'' Neighbors said Mrs. Alphonso told them that she had just finished saying a novena, a nine-day series of prayers, to St. Jude last week when she went to the bathroom to get something from the medicine cabinet. As she reached for the door, she saw the crosses reflected in the cabinet mirror. ``It's a beautiful sight, it really is,'' neighbor Dolores Wattingney said Friday. ``Now, she's had people there to see it all week. Hundreds of people, especially the last few nights.''

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Leader Says He Doubts Talks Will Start as Planned
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's president, again accusing the Kremlin of foot-dragging, said he doubts talks will begin at the end of November as planned to discuss the Baltic republic's independence, Tass reported Sunday. ``The Soviet leadership is forcing a conflict in relations with Lithuania, evidently not willing to begin talks,'' President Vytautas Landsbergis was quoted as saying in an interview with the Soviet news agency. Leaders of the Baltic republics met Saturday with Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov and discussed the budget of the Soviet Union and its republics for 1991. At a second round of talks Oct. 20, Lithuanian and Soviet officials agreed to try to start formal negotiations on secession at the end of November. But Landsbergis said he suspected the talks won't begin then. ``In spite of humiliations, provocations and inadequate behavior on the Soviet side, Lithuanian representatives are doing everything possible not to let the preparations for talks to be interrupted,'' the news agency quoted Landsbergis as saying. The sides have been divided over whether the meetings by their delegations could be considered negotiations or merely talks to plan for negotiations. Lithuania wants the Kremlin to agree to certain guidelines before official talks start, while the Soviet side has said it considers the negotiations already under way. The delegations first met in early October. Lithuania had agreed during the summer to suspend its March 11 declaration of independence in return for the Kremlin's assent to begin the dialogue and end an economic embargo of Lithuania. The delegations agreed after their first session to conduct their economic and trade relations for 1991 as equal partners, while continuing to discuss Lithuania's move toward independence.

DOC.HEAD: Macdeonians Vote in Free Elections
DOC.TEXT: Macedonians voted Sunday in the first free parliamentary elections in more than 50 years in Yugoslavia's poorest republic. The elections are viewed as a crucial test for Yugoslavian Premier Ante Markovic, a pragmatic economic reformer trying to hold this fractious country together. Markovic's new Alliance of Reformist Forces is contesting an election for the first time. Opinion polls have shown the alliance about even with the reconstituted Communist Party. An Albanian nationalist party and Macedonian nationalists also are vying in the elections for a 120-seat, single-chamber legislature. A good showing in Macedonia would boost the alliance's chances in elections schedled for the coming weeks in the republics of Bosnia-Hercegovina, Montenegro and Serbia. The national news agency Tanjug reported the overall turnout from the approximately 1.37 million eligible Macedonian voters was 50 percent by 4 p.m. Polls closed at 7 p.m. Television said the results were slow coming in from isolated villages in the mountainous republic, located at Yugoslavia's southernmost tip and bordered by Albania, Greece and Bulgaria. No results were expected until late Monday, election officials said. Runoff votes will be held Nov. 25 for seats that produce no outright winner. It was the first multiparty vote here since 1938. The Communists, now called the Party of Democratic Change, support Markovic's reform programs and have left open the possibility of forming a coalition with his alliance. The Alliance of Reformist Forces was not formed in time to contest last spring's first multiparty elections in the northern republics of Slovenia and Croatia. Center-right parties ousted the ruling Communists in those republics and now are pushing for Yugoslavia to be reconstituted as a looser confederacy. ``The alliance offers the only chance to keep Yugoslavia together in the long run and to turn it into a modern, prosperous democracy,'' said Rode Marinovski, a Skopje lawyer, as he waited to vote. ``I'm convinced we will do very well here,'' said Stojan Andov, leader of Markovic's party in Macedonia, after casting his vote in Skopje, the state capital about 275 miles south of Belgrade. Markovic's personal popularity grew rapidly after he became premier in March and helped control inflation. But his free-market economic reforms have pitted him against the hard-line communist leadership of the country's largest republic, Serbia. Croatian and Slovenian leaders also are wary of Markovic's efforts to keep the nation more tightly unified as a federation. From 40,000 to 50,000 ethnic Albanians working as guest workers in Western Europe were reported to have returned to Macedonia to vote, and the Albanian Party of Democratic Prosperity was expected to do well. Ethnic Albanians account for over 20 percent of Macedonia's 2.2 million population. Two other nationalist parties are taking part: the Macedonian Action Party and the radical Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization, which was established 100 years ago to fight Turkish control of Macedonia. The radical nationalists claim Macedonia was unjustly divided in 1913 among Serbia, Bulgaria and Greece. They want to form a ``Greater Macedonia'' that would include regions of Greece and Bulgaria.

DOC.HEAD: Illegally Killed Deer Cost Hunters Money, Truck and Nearly Their Lives
DOC.TEXT: Two deer killed illegally cost a pair of hunters $840, their pickup truck and nearly their lives, wildlife officials say. The hunters recently crossed into Wyoming from South Dakota. On their way back, they shot two bucks using a spotlight, the state Game and Fish Department said. ``After making the kill, they decided to hightail it across the border, where they could gut the deer and claim them as being taken in South Dakota,'' the department said. However, about one mile from the South Dakota line, the pickup veered off the road and rolled down a hill, the department said. Details of the accident on Nov. 4 were not immediately clear. The men, who were not identified by wildlife officials, left the scene of the accident, which led authorities to the deer. The truck was destroyed, but they escaped with only bumps and bruises. ``It was a bad wreck,'' said Newcastle Game Warden Scott Talbott. ``They were both lucky they had their seat belts on or they might have been killed.'' The hunters were charged with taking deer without a license. Each was fined $420 and sentenced to six months probation.

DOC.HEAD: Algerian Tribunal Plans to Try Bush
DOC.TEXT: A group of prominent Algerians announced plans Sunday to hold a tribunal next month against President Bush on charges including crimes against humanity. The group said it plans to hold the proceedings in the Algerian capital, Algiers, on Dec. 10. Foremost among the charges will be ``threatening peace and world security by his preparation for an aggressive war against Iraq,'' the group said in a communique. The Algerian tribunal will be headed by Ali Ammar Louar, former president of Algeria's bar association. It will be made up of academics, lawyers and intellectuals active in human rights, the group said. The tribunal is apparently not sponsored by the Algerian government. It would have no way of enforcing its sentence. In its statement, the group said the U.S.-led economic blockade of Iraq is a crime under ``terms of the international convention for prevention of and punishment for genocide.'' The sanctions, approved by the United Nations, were imposed after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Mazowiecki Calls for Unity on Independence Day
DOC.TEXT: In a speech marking the 72nd anniversary of the rebirth of Poland, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki said Sunday that Poles should ``rise beyond divisions'' to continue their unprecedented democratic reforms. On Nov. 11, 1918, the Polish Republic was proclaimed following 123 years of partition among the Russian, German and Austrians empires. Sunday marked the first time the date had been observed as an official holiday since World War II. Poland was invaded by Germany in 1939 and dominated after the war by the Soviet Union. The Solidarity labor movement forced the Communists to hold the first free elections in eastern Europe since the war in 1989. In the country's first popular presidential elections Nov. 25, Mazowiecki is pitted against Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, his former ally. Mazowiecki said history gives his countrymen an important ``source of trust for success in the current struggle,'' but warned that it also ``obliges us to be responsible for today and the future.'' ``We have been carrying out for over a year the vision of Poland as an independent and democratic state,'' Mazowiecki said. ``Rejecting revolutionary methods, we in fact have made revolutionary changes of the system.'' ``I trust that in the name of what we have achieved so far ... we manage to rise beyond divisions to continue the great task of transforming Poland,'' he said. The rivalry of the longtime allies has deeply divided Polish society, but both Mazowiecki and Walesa have stressed the need for national unity in further restructuring of the economy. Mazowiecki spoke at Warsaw's Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in celebrations that marked the restoration of inscriptions commemorating Poland's 1914-1920 struggle for independence. The original inscriptions, bearing the names of battlefields where Polish soldiers fought successfully the Soviet Red Army, were removed in 1945.

DOC.HEAD: River Accident Kills 21 in Zaire
DOC.TEXT: A small boat carrying 41 passengers capsized in the Zaire River near Brazzaville, and 21 people were killed, officials said. The boat overturned about 50 yards from shore after leaving Brazzaville, a western city in this central African country, officials said Saturday. Fishermen rescued the survivors. Authorities gave no information on the cause of the accident, which occurred Friday. It was the second accident in two days on the river. On Wednesday, a floating platform that services boats at the same crossing collapsed. Casualty figures from that accident have not been released.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Officer: Military Was Prepared to Attack Swedes
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union was prepared to use military force to free a Soviet submarine that ran aground in Swedish waters nine years ago, a Soviet officer said in an article published Sunday. Vasily Besedin, then the political officer aboard the submarine, said Soviet warships were waiting in international waters off the Swedish coast. ``They were assigned to force their way through and bring home the submarine if attempts were made to seize it,'' Besedin was quoted as saying in the article. The Soviet submarine ran aground near a major Swedish naval base in the Karlskrona archipelago on Oct. 27, 1981. Sweden waited seven days before returning the vessel. Stuck on a rock for all to see, the Whiskey Class U137 submarine became known as ``Whiskey on the Rocks.'' The incident soured relations between Sweden and its powerful neighbor for years. The article in the Dagens Nyheter newspaper, published in Stockholm, was an account told to Soviet military journalist Vladimir Verbitsky. Swedish Navy Captain Karl Andersson told the national news agency TT that the Soviet forces in the area ``would not have had enough strength'' to take back the submarine. Andersson was one of the officers who interrogated the Soviet crew. ``Also, the political price for an attack against Sweden would have been too high,'' he said. In the article, Besedin echoed Moscow's official excuse that the U137 made a navigational error. According to Besedin, navigation standards were low aboard, and the crew had no idea of where it was when the vessel ran aground. Dagens Nyheter said Besedin lost his apartment, his savings, his wife and was forced to take a job on a road gang when he returned to the Soviet Union. However, he was allowed back in military service after a few months and now serves as a political officer at a coastal unit.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Offers to Attend Summit, But Wants Say on Time, Place, Agenda
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Saddam in interview saying not all countries against him; picks up 7th graf pvs, ```The proposed ..
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush-Gulf Strategy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said Sunday it would attend a proposed Arab summit if the agenda includes the Palestinian question and if it is consulted on the time and place. The Iraqi offer came in response to an appeal by Morocco's King Hassan II, who said such a meeting would be a ``new and last chance'' for a peaceful solution. Iraq's ruling Revolutionary Command Council, led by President Saddam Hussein, went into emergency session to discuss the matter, an official statement read on state television said. It said Iraq was willing to attend the summit if it were consulted in advance on the timing and location and agenda, and if the topics included the Palestinian question. In a separate interview broadcast in London on Sunday, Saddam repeated his call for an international dialogue on the crisis and said he did not think the world was united against him.
