He acknowledged that the major powers and ``a number of countries'' were lined up against Iraq, ``but to say that the world is unified against Iraq is indeed not a correct thing to say.'' ``This is not just our impression,'' he said in the Saturday interview with Britain's Independent Television News. ``In the statements of the U.S. and Britain, they themselves are voicing their concern that the unity - so-called unity against Iraq - is perhaps ... suffering from a split.'' Asked if Iraq was ready to leave Kuwait, Saddam said:``We are ready to enter into deep dialogue as to the requirements for security in our region. ... ``If all parties concerned ... sat around one table we are confident that these parties will reach serious and deep solutions to all the issues, in the forefront of which will be the Palestinian issue.'' In its statement about the possible Arab summit, Saddam's government also suggested it would not allow certain topics to be discussed at the gathering, if it takes place. ``The proposed summit should not be part of efforts to prepare the political theater as a cover for American aggression against Iraq and the Arab nation,'' the Iraqi statement said. Unlike an Aug. 10 summit in Egypt, where 12 of 21 Arab League members voted to send troops to Saudi Arabia, any new summit must not be a ``cover for bringing in U.S. invasion forces,'' the Iraqi statement said. The summit should be preceded by serious consultations ``among the principal parties concerned with the subject and with all Arabs in general,'' it said. In calling for the summit, the Moroccan monarch said if there were war in the Persian Gulf region, it would ``penetrate every household from the gulf to the Atlantic.'' ``Let us gather together and see what decisions we can take ... to give to all what they deserve so that Kuwait returns to what it used to be and that Iraq is a satisfied and satisfying member at the heart of our Arab family,'' the king said. Morocco has been outspoken among Arab nations in its criticism of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. It has sent 1,200 soldiers to Saudi Arabia and 500 troops to the United Arab Emirates as part of the multinational military buildup against Iraq. Hassan suggested meeting in a week in the Moroccan capital of Rabat, but the Iraqi response appeared to reject this in favor of a more neutral site. The idea of a new Arab summit has been brought up a number of times since the crisis broke out, but one has never been agreed on. Many leaders, including Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, have said an Arab solution would be the best way to end the standoff. In his statement, the king again criticized Iraq's annexation of Kuwait. ``Iraq cannot erase in one stroke the Kuwaiti state to make it one of its provinces,'' he said. `` The Kuwaiti people cannot lose day by day their identity to become Iraqi.'' The Palestine Liberation Organization issued a statement from PLO headquarters in Tunisia saying it agreed with King Hassan's initiative. The PLO statement stopped short, however, of saying that PLO leader Yasser Arafat would attend an extraordinary summit.

DOC.HEAD: China Said to Warn Saddam It Won't Veto Use-of-Force Measure
With AM-Gulf-Kuwaiti Volunteers, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Saddam comments on unity against him; picks up 7th graf pvs, `The Baghdad ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1-3
DOC.TEXT: China's foreign minister arrived in Baghdad on Sunday carrying bad news for Saddam Hussein: China will not block the U.N. Security Council from authorizing the use of force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait, a Chinese diplomat said. Such a measure has been drafted by the United States, diplomats and U.S. officials said last week, but had not yet been circulated among the other permanent members of the Security Council. Iraq had reportedly pinned its veto hopes on China. Meanwhile, Iraq said Sunday it would attend a proposed Arab summit meeting if it was consulted on the agenda, timing and location and if the agenda included the Arab-Israeli conflict. ``The proposed summit should not be part of efforts to prepare the political theater as a cover for American aggression against Iraq and the Arab nation,'' said an Iraqi statement read on state television. The offer came in response to an appeal by Morocco's King Hassan II, who urged an extraordinary Arab summit on the gulf crisis. He said such a meeting would be a ``new and last chance'' for a peaceful solution. In a separate interview broadcast Sunday in London, Saddam said he did not think the world was united against him. The major powers and ``a number of countries'' are against Iraq, ``but to say that the world is unified against Iraq is indeed not a correct thing to say,'' Saddam said on Independent Television News, which interviewed him Saturday night in Baghdad. ``This is not just our impression,'' he added. ``In the statements of the U.S. and Britain, they themselves are voicing their concern that the unity - so-called unity against Iraq - is perhaps ... suffering from a split.'' ``The U.S. and Britain pushed the (U.N.) Security Council into adopting hastily taken resolutions against Iraq and once ... countries began to realize or gauge things in accordance with the historical background,'' they began to change their attitudes, he said. Some recent reports have said the U.S. government differs with some allies -among them China, France and the Soviet Union - on a timetable for any military action to oust Saddam from Kuwait. The Baghdad government also denounced food hoarders and announced the price of rice would increase, although it did not specify how much. Iraq has weathered three months of economic sanctions aimed at breaking its grip on Kuwait, which it overran Aug. 2. Before the embargo, Iraq imported about 70 percent of its food. In September, it began rationing essential foodstuffs such as rice, wheat, milk, sugar and cooking oil. The Iraqi move to punish hoarders of grain came at a top-level meeting attended by Saddam, the official Iraqi News Agency said. It said the punishment would be ``strict'' but gave no details. The Chinese foreign minister, Qian Qichen, arrived in Baghdad for talks with Saddam. Before leaving Jordan, Qian said China differed with the United States on the use of force and would pursue diplomacy as long as there was ``a glimmer of hope'' that conflict could be avoided. But a Chinese diplomat in the Iraqi capital, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Qian would tell Saddam that while China would not support a resolution authorizing force, it would not veto it either. China has veto power, along with the other four permanent members of the Security Council - the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union. Iraqi officials had said Saddam's hopes for a veto rested with China. Qian was speaking first with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz and was to meet with Saddam later Sunday. Vice President Dan Quayle flew to Tokyo for the enthronement of Emperor Akihito, and was expected to hold talks on the gulf crisis with a dozen world leaders while there. During the flight from Washington on Sunday, Quayle conferred with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, who traveled to Tokyo with him. A few more foreign hostages were freed Sunday. Eight Italian men arrived in Amman, Jordan, but hundreds of other Italians and other foreigners remain captive in Iraq. The Italians arrived aboard the same plane that carried David Lange, the former New Zealand prime minister, who went to Baghdad to try to win the release of his compatriots. He said 16 New Zealanders were still in Iraq, but that he hoped for ``good news'' about them. Some Western governments, including that of the United States, have criticized private hostage-freeing efforts by former leaders like Lange, saying the emissaries are manipulated by Saddam. Lange, asked about that, retorted: ``The U.S. has this remarkable affinity for misjudging the political climate of the moment.'' Britain, meanwhile, said it was expelling two Iraqis, apparently for attempting to break the trade sanctions. The Home Office said Sunday the two must leave the country by Tuesday ``because of their involvement in procurement on behalf of the government of Iraq.'' It provided no details. In other developments: -The State Department said Sunday that Secretary of State James A. Baker III would discuss the Persian Gulf situation with Canada's foreign minister Joseph Clark on Tuesday in Bermuda. Baker returned Saturday from an eight-day diplomatic mission to Europe and the Middle East, where he consulted with officials from nine nations on the gulf crisis. -Two American hostages released by Iraq on Friday have been discharged from a military hospital in Wiesbaden, Germany, a U.S. Air Force spokesman said Sunday. Spokesman Capt. Tom Gilroy said he did not know whether the two, Don and Brenda Swanke of Westlake Village, Calif., would return home immediately. -Some congressional Democrats on Sunday urged President Bush to consult closely with allies and Congress before launching any military offensive to oust Iraq from Kuwait. ``The decision to go to war ought to be a shared responsibility, it ought not to be made by one person, even if that person is the president of the United States,'' said Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said Congress must vote before America goes to war. The two spoke in television interviews.

DOC.HEAD: Health Officials Stumped on Student Illness
DOC.TEXT: An unknown disease sickened 300 University of Colorado students over the weekend, and state health officials said Sunday they suspected food poisoning but could find no common cause. The illness, which broke out Friday night and continued to plague students Sunday at the on-campus Wardenburg Health Center, was characterized by vomiting, low-grade fever and diarrhea. Officials said those symptoms suggest food poisoning, but the outbreak perplexed health officials because they had been unable to find a common food linking the cases. The students ate in several dormitory cafeterias, as well as off campus. The majority of students were treated at Wardenburg for dehydration and sent home. Two were hospitalized Saturday night, but health center officials would not comment about them Sunday. ``It appears to be a food-borne illness outbreak, centered mostly in dorm residents,'' said Dennis Lenaway, an epidemiologist with the Boulder County health department. Dr. Paul Simon, a state epidemiologist, agreed that it was probably food poisoning, but said health officials didn't know what kind. ``It looks to me like it's some sort of infectious disease - food poisoning caused by an infection,'' Simon said. ``But at this point we just don't have enough information.'' If it is an infection-based outbreak, the students could have eaten the tainted food up to three days before becoming sick, Simon said. ``There are so many dorms involved,'' said Dr. Ingrid Hagan, Wardenburg's chief of staff. ``I myself saw several patients that didn't eat in the dorms, they ate off campus. We took only a very brief history as far as what they ate but there doesn't seem to be a common denominator.'' An additional 15 to 18 students went to Boulder Community Hospital on Friday, said hospital spokeswoman Kathy Stephens. None of those students was hospitalized. County health officials delivered questionnaires to the dormitories on Saturday in hope of pinpointing what caused the outbreak. ``We hope to narrow it down to a meal, or, even better, a food item. We're hoping we can get that detailed,'' said Lenaway. ``We'll just have to see how things sort themselves out.''

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Seeking Death Penalty in Transient Killings
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor said Sunday he will seek the death penalty for a woman convicted of murdering five transients to cover up a cattle theft scheme. The jury that convicted Faye Copeland on Saturday was to return Monday to decide between a life sentence or execution. Mrs. Copeland's attorney, David Miller, said he will request a new trial, calling it a ``major issue'' that the judge did not allow a psychologist to testify about her husband's domination over her life. Mrs. Copeland's husband, 75-year-old Ray Copeland, is scheduled for trial Jan. 24 on murder charges in the case. A court must first determine whether he is mentally competent to stand trial. His lawyers contend he is senile. A jury in Livingston County in rural, northwest Missouri convicted Mrs. Copeland, 69, of five counts of first-degree murder. The bodies of the five men were found in fall 1989 near farms where Copeland had done odd jobs, after a tip from another drifter who had worked for the couple. All had been shot in the head. Prosecutors said the couple had the transients open bank accounts in their names and buy cattle at various sales. The Copelands then resold the cattle, keeping the proceeds and killing the transients before the checks could be traced, they said. Townspeople had mixed feelings about Mrs. Copeland's part in the slayings. ``There was feeling both ways,'' said resident Leroy Butts, who watched portions of the trial. ``A lot of people felt kind of sorry for her. But all those men were dead and you wonder how she didn't know anything about it.'' Mrs. Copeland buried her face in her hands and sobbed after the verdict was read, saying, ``I never done nothing.'' Miller said he will call a Kansas City psychologist to testify about battered-wife syndrome during the trial's penalty phase. The testimony was ruled inadmissible during the trial. Miller said he would also call six other witnesses, including family members, to show a pattern of domination in Mrs. Copeland's life. The defense had tried to prove she did not participate in the killings and was not privy to her husband's business dealings.

DOC.HEAD: First Heart-Liver Transplant Just Wanted to be an Average Teen-ager
DOC.TEXT: Stormie Jones just wanted to be an average teen-ager, free of the medical complications and media glare that came with being the world's first heart-liver transplant patient, friends said Sunday. ``She wished everybody would treat her normal instead of like she had an operation, because she didn't like everybody asking her how she felt or if she was feeling OK,'' said Stormie's best friend, Crystal Millikan. On Sunday, Crystal and others who loved Stormie mourned the death of the 13-year-old girl who had inspired family, friends and well-wishers with her determination and courage during a six-year battle with illness. ``I'm going to miss her a lot,'' Crystal said at the apartment complex where she and Stormie had lived with their families in this Fort Worth suburb. Stormie died Sunday at a Pittsburgh hospital where she was flown Saturday after complaining of flu-like symptoms. She became the first heart-liver transplant recipient on Valentine's Day, 1984, at the age of 6. She received a second liver on Feb. 20 of this year. Crystal, also 13, said Stormie, like most teen-agers, liked to shop at the local mall and spend nights at her friend's house. Stormie had wanted to return to school this year. But after three weeks in the seventh grade at Brewer Middle School she was forced home by fatigue. Still, she dreamed of becoming a veterinarian and had hoped to write an autobiography titled ``In The Darkness'' to reflect what she thought about when she fell asleep. Crystal said Stormie recently gave her a poster she had drawn with a bear and jack-in-the-box with the caption ``Friends are friends forever.'' As Stormie handed over the poster, she said, ``Don't forget me.'' Despite her desire to be average, Stormie was considered special in White Settlement, where a local discount store helped raise money to pay for her medical expenses. The Sam's Club store said it sold out its supply of T-shirts emblazoned with the caption, ``Texas is known for Stormie weather.'' ``I just wanted more for her. She deserved more,'' said Crystal's mother, Teresa Millikan, who spearheaded the fund-raising efforts. `She was God's walking angel. She touched so many people's hearts.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev, Yeltsin Huddle in Kremlin
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to recast lede, clarifies that two-hour meeting was one-on-one; Picks up 4th graf, `The popular ...'
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev and rival Boris Yeltsin met Sunday in the Kremlin, and one report said they discussed emergency measures to feed the Soviet people and reform their crumbling economy. Gorbachev, the Soviet president, and Yeltsin, the president of the Russian republic, met one-on-one for two hours, the independent Interfax news agency reported. It was their first substantive meeting since an attempt at reconciliation over economic reform broke down in late summer. The earlier failed attempt at reconciliation over economic policies put Yeltsin's Russian republic on a collision course with the central Soviet government. The popular Yeltsin, whom Gorbachev ousted from the Communist Party Politburo in 1986, has criticized the Soviet leader for not reforming fast enough. After their private meeting, Gorbachev and Yeltsin were joined by Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov and two officials from the Russian republic, Vice President Ruslan Khasbulatov and Prime Minister Ivan Silaev, Interfax said. The conversation between Gorbachev and Yeltsin was conducted in a ``businesslike, principled atmosphere,'' Interfax said, without quoting any sources. Among the questions discussed were the Russian republic's role in possible radical economic reforms and ``urgent measures'' to provide food and consumer goods, Interfax said. The official Tass news agency, also without quoting sources, said the leaders discussed ``current problems,'' the transition to a market economy and the union treaty - Gorbachev's plan for holding the splintering 15 Soviet republics together as a loose confederation. On Nov. 1, Russia began its own 500-day plan for converting to a free market economy, conflicting with a more cautious plan endorsed by Gorbachev and approved by the national legislature. The republic's legislature also has said that it, and not the central government, has the right to control Russia's considerable natural resources of oil, coal and diamonds. Russia comprises about two-thirds of the Soviet Union. The disagreement, which cast doubt on the success of Soviet economic reforms, has become a matter of sharp public debate, with pleas to the two leaders to reconcile. In a commentary Sunday, Tass said the ``tug of war threatens to jeopardize all efforts.'' In a letter published in Sunday's conservative Sovietskaya Rossiya newspaper, Yeltsin was criticized for his differences with Gorbachev. ``The path you are calling for is not Russia's right path,'' said the authors, a group of veterans from Smolensk region west of Moscow. ``We condemn the policy of confrontation with the center that you (Yeltsin) and many Russian parliamentarians are pursuing.'' Radical legislator Oleg Kalugin, a former KGB general and ardent Gorbachev critic, said Sunday that Gorbachev ``has to move closer to Yeltsin or nothing constructive will come out of it.'' Gorbachev and Yeltsin stood together on Wednesday's Revolution Day holiday reviewing the traditional parade in Red Square, although Yeltsin also marched later that day in anti-government demonstrations that urged Gorbachev and other Soviet leaders resign.

DOC.HEAD: Bombs Destroy Two Cars At Air Force Base, Fire Set In Office
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8 grafs for last 2 grafs, `Sgt. Randy ...' to UPDATE with details, comment, background; ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: A fire bomb was set off at an Air Force office building early Sunday and small bombs destroyed two government-owned cars, officials said. The fire did little damage to the Office of Special Investigations and no one was injured in the car bombings at about 4 a.m. at this base adjoining Fort Lewis near Tacoma, said Master Sgt. Gloria Rayford. No arrests were made, nor were investigators immediately able to determine who was responsible, Rayford said. She said she didn't know whether the three devices were detonated with timing devices or fuses. ``There was no one at the scene when it happened,'' Rayford said. Terrorism was not suspected because no note was left nor did anyone call to claim responsibility, said Air Force Sgt. Randy Mitchell. The FBI and the Pierce County fire marshall's office were assisting in the investigation, Mitchell said. The Office of Special Investigations handles security at the 5,000-acre Air Force base and crimes above the level of drunkenness or brawling. ``They're sort of the FBI for the Air Force,'' Rayford said. Its building is a low structure situated beside a block-long parking lot and across the street from base headquarters. The explosive devices apparently were placed above the left rear wheel of each of the late-model, brown sedans used by investigators. Those investigating the bombing said they did not believe military-type explosives had been used. A small piece of pipe, about 1{ inches long with a cap on one end, appeared to have been blown about 100 feet from one car. Security was tight after the bombings, with military police checking identification on every vehicle entering the base. The base's military police generally do more more than infrequent spot checks of vehicles entering the base. About 4,800 personnel are based at McChord, and 1,300 to 1,500 civilians work there.

DOC.HEAD: Striking Daily News Workers Publish ``Real News''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 11th graf, `Hoge said ...' to include background on homeless enlisted. Pick up 12th graf, `Sunday's edition ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News stepped up its efforts Sunday to create a network of people across the city to sell the newspaper despite an aggressive boycott campaign by striking workers. The paper ran a full-page ad Sunday saying it had ``immediate needs for individuals who want to own, operate, and direct their own work force selling newspapers.'' The ad said in large letters: ``UNLIMITED INCOME.'' Meanwhile, strikers fanned out over the city to start distribution of what union officials said were a million copies of an eight-page, free newspaper titled ``Real News.'' All the stories in ``Real News'' were written by Daily News writers who have been on strike since Oct. 25. ``We wanted to show that the striking employees are the heart and soul of the Daily News and that we're capable of producing a better-quality paper than the scab rag Jim Hoge is putting out right now,'' said striking columnist Juan Gonzalez, referring to the Daily News publisher. Gonzalez coordinated distribution efforts at the Newspaper Guild headquarters Sunday. Gonzalez said ``Real News'' is aimed at giving the strikers' version of the labor dispute. The articles detail the history of the strike, incidents that have involved violece, interviews with news vendors and profiles of striking pressmen and drivers. ``Real News'' will be handed out Monday and Tuesday at churches, hospitals, hotels, housing projects and subway stations, Gonzalez said. On Sunday, striking staffers distributed ``Real News'' at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., and began dropping off bundles to other strikers and individual unions. The News has published each day during the strike, but circulation has been a major problem with some vendors refusing to sell it and others claiming they got no deliveries. Some vendors have claimed threats by striking drivers. Hoge said last week that 600,000 papers were printed each day. Pre-strike circulation was about 1.09 million copies daily, making the News the nation's third-largest metropolitan daily. On Friday, the poor and homeless were recruited by the paper as sales people. One recruit, Eddy Nadreau, said the News had called the Brooklyn shelter where he lives, offering $6 an hour and a percentage of sales. Sunday's edition of the News quoted one newsstand operator, Luis Rivera, saying that customers were intimidated by two men who came in, went through stacks of papers and checked the papers everyone was reading. ``Everyone was scared,'' Rivera said. Strikers, on the other hand, are protesting security forces hired by the Daily News. George E. McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, the umbrella group representing the 2,600 strikers in nine unions, sent a telegram to Mayor David Dinkins and Police Commissioner Lee Brown requesting a meeting Monday to discuss the security guards' tactics. ``This army of combat-ready troops comprised of men in ski masks and combat boots and black bodysuits are unleashing a reign of terror on the streets of New York City,'' the letter read in part. ``Troops are using martial arts sticks and other illegal and life threatening weapons ... These mercenary efforts must be stopped before they take an innocent life.'' There was no immediate Daily News comment on the letter Sunday; spokeswoman Lisa Robinson did not return a call. The strike began with a dispute at the paper's Brooklyn plant in which some drivers walked off the job. As others left, the News began bringing in replacement workers, calling the job action a strike. The shutdown spread to other unions that have been working without labor contracts since March 30.

DOC.HEAD: Teen-age Heart-Liver Recipient Dies at 13
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf pvs, `An autopsy ...' to UPDATE that preliminary autopsy was inconclusive. SUBS 3 grafs for last graf, `Ms. McMahon ...' to UPDATE with details on girl's warmth toward fellow patients. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY10, NY11, DN3
DOC.TEXT: Stormie Jones, the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient, died Sunday at age 13 after a six-year struggle that inspired well-wishers across the country. The Texas teen-ager was flown to Pittsburgh's Children's Hospital from Dallas late Saturday after she complained of flu-like symptoms. At the hospital, Stormie deteriorated throughout the morning and died at 9:52 a.m., said Dr. Jorge Reyes, a staff physician. ``She deserved more,'' said Teresa Millikan, a family friend who spearheaded efforts to raise funds for Stormie's hospital expenses. ``She was God's walking angel. She touched so many people's hearts.'' Within hours of her arrival at the hospital, Stormie's blood pressure dropped, Reyes said. She became lethargic, then suffered a heart attack, he said. Doctors tried for more than an hour to resuscitate her. ``She presented acute respiratory distress and had a cardiac arrest,'' Reyes told reporters. ``Things happened with incredible speed,'' said hospital spokeswoman Lynn McMahon said. Stormie was alert when she was taken to Children's Hospital and it had not appeared to be an emergency, she said. A preliminary autopsy performed Sunday was inconclusive, she said. Stormie was 6 when she received a heart and liver in a historic transplant operation Feb. 14, 1984. The operation was necessary because she was born with a condition that put her cholesterol levels at 10 times normal. Hepatitis damaged that liver and this year she returned to Pittsburgh and received a second liver Feb. 20. In July, she was again treated for hepatitis, which damaged her second transplanted liver. Doctors said it was a mystery how she contracted hepatitis. Stormie, of the Fort Worth suburb of White Settlement, and her mother, Lois Purcell, left Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport on Saturday evening. Millikan said Saturday that Stormie had not been feeling well since midweek. ``She doesn't feel good, she's tired,'' she said. ``She hasn't been able to sleep for the past three nights. She's had it pretty rough.'' Her daughter, Crystal, who was Stormie's best friend, said the ailing girl never felt comfortable under the media's glare and wanted more than anything to feel like a normal teen-ager. ``She wished everybody would treat her normal instead of like she had an operation, because she didn't like everybody asking her how she felt or if she was feeling OK,'' Crystal said, tears welling in her eyes. ``Nobody in the world was as sweet or kind as her. There'll be nobody like her,'' she said. Stormie, who turned 13 in May, had hoped to write an autobiography titled ``In The Darkness.'' The book was to be ``about my life, my family, all the pet animals I've had,'' she said earlier this year. The blonde teen-ager said she liked frightening books, movies and television programs, such as the cable horror series ``Tales From The Crypt'' and the movie ``Pet Sematary.'' ``I feel better when I write my thoughts down,'' Stormie said. Stormie took the experimental anti-rejection drug FK-506, which has been approved for testing exclusively at the University of Pittsburgh. A few exceptions have been made for patients elsewhere. Until a year ago, Stormie had been taking cyclosporine, an anti-rejection drug that lowers the body's ability to fight infection. Researchers say FK-506 is more powerful and causes fewer side effects. Any transplant patient is susceptible to infection because anti-rejection drugs weaken the immune system, Reyes said. ``I wouldn't particularly focus on the FK-506 as a specific cause,'' he said. Stormie was at the hospital for several hours before doctors could tell her heart was affected, he said. She got some sleep during the night and asked for water when she awoke, Reyes said. Her mother was at her side. ``She was really with us 100 percent before this happened,'' Reyes said. The hospital staff liked and admired Stormie, he said. ``She was a happy girl. She certainly enjoyed fighting us as much as she could,'' Reyes said. Stormie once bought a book on Chinese to help her communicate with a 3-year-old Chinese fellow patient. ``She did that kind of thing all the time,'' said Ms. McMahon, the hospital spokeswoman. ``She was just so highly regarded by other children. She went to great length to take the time to play with them and talk with them.'' Ms. McMahon said the staff planned a memorial service. Funeral arrangements were pending.

DOC.HEAD: Vandals Damage Statue of Polish Priest and Leave Political Message
DOC.TEXT: Vandals knocked the head off the newly dedicated statue of a murdered priest who championed democracy in Poland and scrawled ``For Lenin, for Stalin'' along the statue base, authorities said Sunday. The 9-foot-tall, 5-foot-wide granite statue was dedicated Oct. 28 in Brooklyn's Greenpoint section to honor the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, a pro-Solidarity Roman Catholic priest killed by Polish secret police in 1984. More than 50,000 Polish immigrants live in Greenpoint. Many of the 1,000 parishioners attending the 11 a.m. Mass at Our Lady of Consolation on Sunday wept when the Rev. John Lazar told them of the vandalism, which occured overnight. No one claimed responsibility. ``Many of the immigrants in the area are from the diocese where he served,'' Lazar said later. ``Many had heard his pro-Solidarity and anti-Communist talks firsthand. Some of them knew him.'' The head of the statue erected at the intersection of Lorimer Street and Bedford Avenue was found in a nearby trash can, said police Officer Scott Bloch. The words, ``Za Lenina Za Stalina,'' Polish for ``For Lenin, for Stalin,'' were scrawled in black paint on the statue base. Lazar said it was a ``tremendous triumph'' for many Polish immigrants to see the statue dedicated at a ceremony attended by Polish Bishop Joseph Wysocki. Now, ``there is shock and disbelief,'' Lazar said. ``Although the priest has been dead for six years he stays very much alive in the hearts and memories of the Polish people.'' He said some Polish residents view the vandalism as an extension of the violence that caused Popieluszko's death. Until the statue was dedicated, private security guards watched the location because threats had been made that the statue would be defaced or destroyed, Lazar said. Popieluszko, whose sermons bolstered the Solidarity labor movement when it was outlawed, was abducted Oct. 19, 1984. His beaten and bound body was pulled from an icy river 11 days later, shocking Poland and galvanizing the anti-Communist movement. Four secret policemen were convicted of the slaying.

DOC.HEAD: Underground Electrical Fire and Explosions Disrupt Downtown Business
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2 grafs for grafs 3-5, `Pacific Gas...' to UPDATE with cause of fires traced. Pickup at 6th graf pvs, ``Shoppers fled ...'
DOC.TEXT: Smoky fires and explosions ripped through underground electrical circuits, closing down one of downtown's busiest shopping districts for five hours. Only a handful of customers lost power, despite the long disruption of traffic and business in the incident Saturday, officials said. The trouble was traced to a break in a water main, which caused a short in electrical equipment at the corner of Sutter Street and Grant Avenue near the southern edge of Chinatown, said Pacific Gas & Electric spokesman Paul Ward. No one was injured. Red smoke began belching out of a manhole at the intersection on Saturday morning. Shoppers fled and merchants closed shop as police, fire, Health Department and PG&E officials rushed to the scene. By early afternoon, it appeared that the blaze had died down, but then explosions blew manhole covers out of the ground in the area. ``It was pretty scary, I thought the mirrors were going to break,'' said Chris Qadir, a clothing salesman. The blaze finally was contained within the conduit of a backup electric system.

DOC.HEAD: Emperor Akihito To Be Formally Enthroned in Controversial Rite
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 17 grafs to UPDATE with new attacks, including one at U.S. base; picks up 13th graf pvs, `A record .... TRIMS thereafter
DOC.TEXT: Enthronement scheduled between 11-11:30 p.m. EST
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: In a solemn, centuries-old rite at the Imperial Palace, Emperor Akihito formally accedes to the Chrysanthemum Throne on Monday, becoming the first Japanese monarch enthroned as a symbol and not a living god. Leftist radicals launched a series of attacks aimed at disrupting the ceremony. They fired missiles at five military bases, including a U.S. naval base, and were blamed with setting fires at religious shrines and train stations. None of the attacks caused injuries. A massive national security operation involving thousands of police was mounted to protect the ceremony and the scores of visiting dignitaries. Clad in ancient court costume, seated atop an elaborate lacquered platform under a curtained canopy encrusted with gold phoenixes and circular mirrors, Akihito will face a courtyard lined with ceremonial banners. Next to him on a smaller platform will be Empress Michiko. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu will lead the 2,500 guests in three cheers of ``Banzai!'' - ``May you live ten thousand years!'' Akihito began his morning rituals by offering private prayers at three wooden shrines inside the heavily guarded Imperial Palace to announce his enthronement to the Sun Goddess and ancestors. Critics say the 30-minute ceremony - and a series of accompanying rites to be held in coming weeks - are based too closely on the traditional religious rituals used for Akihito's father and grandfather, who were enthroned as living gods. Under Japan's postwar constitution, the emperor is simply a national symbol. In one controversial element of the rite, Akihito's raised dais is said to be patterned after one used by the sun goddess, from whom tradition says the Japanese imperial line is descended. Critics say that is an implied symbol of divinity. The government is reportedly spending $95 million on the rites, much of it for security. Opponents say state funding of the ceremonies, linked to Japan's indigenous Shinto religion, violates the constitutional separation of religion and state. The radical left has been particularly incensed because of the legacy of imperial militarism in Japan. The projectiles were launched at three suburban bases of the military and at a base in western Tokyo, police said. No damage was reported. Another missile was fired outside the U.S. naval base at Atsugi, 24 miles southwest of Tokyo. The base was apparently the target of that failed attack. Three train fires stopped service on two commuter lines, and in separate incidents, two major subway lines were shut down because of smoke. Fires also broke out at four Shinto shrines in Tokyo, including one less than a mile from Akihito's residence. Police said all were believed started by extremists. No injuries were immediately reported, but tw shrines were destroyed. On Sunday, two bombs exploded at the house of U.S. Consul General Gregory L. Johnson in Nishinomiya, in western Japan. Police said they caused little damage and no injuries. It was not immediately clear whether the explosions were connected with the enthronement. A record 37,000 police, including reinforcements from a majority of Japan's 47 prefectures, have been mobilized for security surrounding the rite. Security was particularly heavy around the downtown palace, where Akihito began his morning rituals by offering private prayers to the sun goddess at a wooden shrine. Dignitaries from 158 countries expected to attend the ceremony include Vice President Dan Quayle, United Nations Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, Supreme Soviet Chairman Anatoly I. Lukyanov and Britain's Prince Charles and Princess Diana. The government has not released the names of Japanese dignitaries invited to the ceremony, because of fear of radical attacks on their homes or businesses. Traffic was sharply restricted or halted along highways and in areas around the palace, but few tie-ups were reported, in part because enthronement day was declared a national holiday and many Tokyoites took advantage of the three-day weekend to leave town. Airlines reported many flights were booked close to capacity. Akihito became emperor immediately upon the death of his father, Emperor Hirohito, in January 1989, but a period of mourning was observed before his formal enthronement. Akihito, 56, was tutored after World War II by an American pacifist, and is the first emperor in modern Japanese history to marry a commoner. He and the empress also raised their three children themselves, rather than have them raised separately by aides, as was the imperial custom. As with Hirohito's funeral, which was attended by representatives of 164 nations, the enthronement provided opportunity for a flurry of diplomatic meetings. Kaifu was scheduled to meet with about 50 foreign officials. On Monday evening, the first of seven banquets scheduled over five days is to be held at the Imperial Palace, with senior Japanese officials and foreign dignitaries attending.

DOC.HEAD: Relatives of U.S. Troops Launch Effort Against Gulf Policy
DOC.TEXT: Relatives of American troops in the Persian Gulf set up a new family support group Sunday that opposes a U.S. military offensive there. The Military Families Support Network was organized by the author of an angry, open letter to President Bush that was publised in The New York Times. Alex Molnar, the father of a Marine in Saudi Arabia, says the group has 2,500 members and chapters in eight states. ``This is the first time I know of that military families and patriotic, mainstream Americans are among the first to voice doubts over American policy,'' he said in a statement. Molnar's letter to the president, published Aug. 23, expressed concerns and fears about the military buildup in the Persian Gulf after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Molnar, an education professor at the University of Wisconsin in Milwaukee, said he received a flood of telephone calls after the letter appeared and decided to form the group. The organization has chapters in New York, California, Texas, Nebraska, Illinois, South Carolina, North Carolina and Tennessee, Molnar said. The group wants Bush to invoke the War Powers Act and allow Congress to decide whether the United States goes to war. However, the organization is calling for a diplomatic solution to the crisis. The group also supports United Nations resolutions condemning Iraq and imposing economic sanctions, but it opposes the massive deployment of American ground forces or a military offensive. Molnar said money raised by the group would be used for an advertising campaign. ``The Vietnam War generation, it seems, is not about to send its children and family members into another war with questionable moral grounding, without a cry for public debate and the consensus of the American people,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Puts Damper on Solar Race
LaserPhoto MAT3
DOC.TEXT: Rain put a damper on the first day of the World Solar Challenge race Sunday, wiping out any chance at the record pace organizers had predicted. Darwin's first consistently rainy day since May delayed the start by an hour. A crowd of several thousand cheered as the event got under way with the announcement: ``Gentlemen, start your solar panels.'' Mostly overcast conditions persisted as the cars headed south toward Adelaide, 1,875 miles away. With the 36 cars from nine countries spread out over 90 miles, a torrential rain forced many drivers to stop and cover their cars. ``It was amazing that the satellite maps showed the only real cloud over Australia this morning was over Darwin,'' said race organizer Hans Tholstrup. The entry from Western Washington University at Bellingham, Wash., took the early lead over Biel University of Switzerland. The leaders were not expected to cover more than 300 miles the first day. The winner of the inaugural event in 1987, General Motors' Sunraycer, traveled almost 450 miles in one day to set a record. Western Washington's car has fore and aft driver positions so the vehicle can point in either direction to take best advantage of the sun's position. Speeds were expected to pick up once the cloud cover dissipated. The cars race nine hours each day, usually stopping before 5 p.m. Sunraycer, the 1987 winner, averaged 42 mph and hit a top speed of 71 mph. It reached Adelaide in 44 hours and 54 minutes, over five days. For much of the route through desolate central Australia, there are no trees, just scrub brush, grass, rocks, and usually plenty of sun. The temperature in the Outback can exceed 120. Entered are 11 cars each from Australia and Japan, eight from the United States and one each from Canada, Switzerland, Germany, Denmark, New Zealand and England. The prize is a trophy of a globe topped by the sun. With oil prices skyrocketing, interest in the solar race is keener than for the first event three years ago. Retired American real estate developer J. Ward Phillips said more than $23.4 million worth of technology was taking part in what he grandly described as ``the most significant event in the history of the universe.'' The lineup reads like a ``Who's Who'' of engineering and automotive technology. GM is sponsoring the top three finishers in a July university race from Florida to Detroit. Japan's Honda Research and Development Co. Ltd. has an entry, and the only British car, under the name of Phil Farrand, is actually from the Williams Formula One Grand Prix team. The solar car has come so far that GM has unveiled a prototype production model, the Impact, which it claims will out-accelerate a Mazda MX-5 sports car to 60 mph. Japan's Kyocera Corp., with an 11-member team, estimates it invested $546,000 to enter its Blue Eagle in this year's race. GM spent about $3.9 million on Sunraycer, now housed in the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C. The difference is due to advancements in silicon cells, which cost a small fraction of the gallium arsenide cells used for Sunraycer.

DOC.HEAD: Man Wounds Two After Dispute Over Dog, Kills Himself After Standoff
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `One of ...' to CORRECT that Carr sted Fillinger was shot trying to calm down gunman and that Fillinger, sted Carr, was shot while walking by. Picks up 6th graf, `Police negotiators ...'
DOC.TEXT: A gunman wounded two people in a traffic dispute over an injured dog, then holed up in his house for eight hours before killing himself, police said. A SWAT team discovered Manuel Ramon dead when it stormed the house Saturday, police Lt. Edward DeVennish said. ``He got into a dispute about a street being blocked because people pulled over in a car to help a wounded animal,'' DeVennish said. Ramon grew angry when people trying to help the dog wouldn't let him pass in his car. One of the injured, Brendon Carr, 19, of Columbus was shot after trying to calm down Ramon, witnesses said. The other, Angela Fillinger, 25, also of Columbus, was shot while walking past the house near Ohio State University. Police negotiators tried to talk Ramon out of the house and fired tear gas after an eight-hour standoff, DeVennish said. Richard Heuring of Cincinnati, a student at Ohio State, said he was standing next to Carr when the gunman opened fire. ``We came outside after we heard screeching tires,'' Heuring said. ``We saw the dog on the ground. ... We were about to go inside when this guy got out of his car and was yelling to move the car.'' Heuring said he and Carr tried to calm the man. ``But the guy shouted, `I don't care about any dog, move the car!''' Heuring said. The injured were listed in fair condition Sunday, a hospital spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecution of Old Rape Cases Unlikely, Police Say
DOC.TEXT: Prosecution of old rape cases that were reopened for investigation is unlikely because alleged victims have been difficult to find or are unwilling to cooperate, police said. The 228 cases were reopened in September after it was revealed one in four reported rapes and attempted rapes last year were classified by police as ``unfounded,'' meaning police determined the rapes did not occur. Police conceded at the time that some of the victims were never contacted by investigators after the initial report. Many of the alleged victims were cocaine users, prostitutes or acquainted with their assailants, police and rape crisis workers said. Subsequent investigation found 79 of 112 alleged rapes reviewed so far did occur, but the prospect for arrests and prosecution is slim, Oakland police Capt. James Hahn said. In some cases, investigators were unable to contact victims, either because they gave incorrect addresses or moved. In other instances, the victims did not respond to investigators or said they did not want to prosecute. ``Some said they were getting their life together and didn't want to pursue the case,'' Hahn said. ``One lady cursed investigators.'' Of 19 cases that remain unfounded, police determined one was reported by a mother who wanted to prevent her daughter from having an affair. Another was reported by a person other than the victim, who told police she had not been raped. Hahn said those were typical of the reasons the rest of the 19 are still considered unfounded. A review of all 228 cases will be completed by next month and presented to the City Council, Hahn said.

DOC.HEAD: New Products, Hype and Recession Talk Expected At Largest Computer Show
DOC.TEXT: The computer industry will trot out new products and crank up its promotion machine as the world's largest annual computer show opens here Monday. But the hype may be overshadowed by the looming recession. Computer sales have been slowing for several years. With the economy as a whole entering a slump, the industry's outlook could darken further. Domestic sales of personal computers fell about 25 percent in September compared with the first eight months of the year, according to Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. However, the economic downturn is not among the dozens of industry and technical topics scheduled for panel discussions during the show, called Comdex Fall. In typical trade-show fashion, the official patter will be upbeat. Among issues that will be addressed by industry experts are multimedia computing, or the use of video, photographs and animation on computers; a related technology called image processing; portable computers; and business opportunities in the ``new Europe.'' The keynote speaker is Bill Gates, the young chairman of software powerhouse Microsoft Corp. Gates is scheduled to talk Monday about the evolution of personal computing and its future. Gates' company has been in the news this year for its software that gives International Business Machines Corp. computers and compatible models many of the ease-of-use features of Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh. Microsoft says it has sold more than 1 million copies of the Windows 3 software since its June introduction. Also scheduled to speak is Gilbert Hyatt, an engineer who in July was granted a patent for his work in developing the microprocessor. The patent award called into question the computer industry's official history, which says the computer-on-a-chip was invented by several Intel Corp. scientists. One of the more important bits of news expected at Comdex won't be announced at a flashy news conference. Instead, semiconductor maker Advanced Micro Devices Inc. will give private demonstrations of its new product, a clone of Intel's extremely popular 386 microprocessor. The 386 chip is the brains of an increasing number of IBM personal computers and compatible models. AMD says its chip is even better than the original. However, the company doesn't plan a full-scale announcment at the show because it has not set the price or availability date for the chip, said AMD spokesman David Frink. Apart from the panel discussions, one of the major attractions of Comdex to those in the industry are the acres and acres of computer products on display. Among the more intriguing devices will be tiny personal computers called notepads and other portable computers that recognize handwriting. Comdex is billed as the nation's largest annual trade show. It virtually takes over Las Vegas this week, with 118,000 conventioneers overflowing hotel rooms and more than 1,800 product exhibitors from 22 countries cramming onto display floors at the Las Vegas Convention Center and five hotels. The 12-year-old gathering is a forum for major computer makers to attract new distributors for their products. It also is used by tiny startup companies to gain a foothold in the vast computer market. Though the show is aimed primarily at computer sellers, it draws computer experts and insiders of all sorts, from trade letter editors to Wall Street analysts. About 1,800 members of the press are expected, organizers say. However, Comdex appears to be losing some of its luster as a place for computer companies to make major announcements, some observers say. ``You get lost in the noise,'' said Esther Dyson, publisher of the computer newsletter Release 1.0 and a Comdex veteran. Plus, she added, with the growth of other computer industry gatherings, ``It's no longer THE big event of the year. ``The industry is getting less cohesive. There are so many different parts and interest groups,'' she said.
